texts.fr: Solange est une femme âgée de 30 ans, fiancée et mère de 04 enfants dont l'âge varie entre entre 05 et 12 ans. elle mène une activité de vente de frais (ignames, patates, tomate) depuis 15 ans dans un marché de la place. elle sollicite ce crédit augmenter son stock permanent de marchandise afin de résoudre le problème de rupture dont elle est souvent victime. elle bénéficie d'une bonne expérience dans le domaine. elle compte dans l'avenir agrandir son comptoir et diversifier sa marchandise afin de mieux assurer les frais de scolarité de ses enfants ainsi que leur condition de vie.
texts.en:
Solange, age 30, is engaged with four children aged 5 to 12. She has been selling fresh produce (yams, potatoes, tomatoes) at a local market for the past 15 years.  

She is seeking this loan to build a permanent stock of merchandise, which would solve the shortage problems that she often faces. She has a good experience in her activity. 

In the future, she would like to expand her business and diversify her stock to help cover her children’s tuition and improve their living conditions.

loans.use: to stock up on merchandise to sell.

loans.name: Cris Katherin

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal LOS EMPRENDEDORES, la socia Cris tiene 25 años de edad y es soltera ,la socia alterna sus actividades diarias trabajando en una empresa privada,la socia trabaja durante el dia en su trabajo, la socia suele viajar cada cierto tiempo en sus vacaciones a diferentes ciudades del pais lo cual le divierte mucho,la socia lleva buen tiempo dedicandose a su trabajo el cual le va bien gracias al empeño que le pone cada dia,la socia desea poder seguir trabajando para de esta forma salir adelante,la socia es ingeniera de profesion.

La socia solicito el credito para sus ahorros y una laptop.


La socia se siente agradecida por el  crédito otorgado y se compromete a cumplir con sus cuotas establecidas.
texts.en:
Cris is 25 years old, single and a member of the community bank Los Emprendedores. She is an engineer by training. She balances her daily activities with working for a private company. Cris says she has been doing this work for a while, and she thinks she does well because of the effort she puts into the business every day. She would like to continue working to get ahead. 

Cris is requesting this loan to []. She says she is grateful for the loan, and promises to make her payments on time.

loans.use: para sus ahorros y una laptop.

loans.name: Los Inversionistas Exitosos Group

texts.es:
La socia Silvia pertenece al banco comunal “Los Inversionistas Exitosos”, el banco está ubicado en el distrito de Cusco y provincia de Cusco.

La socia Silvia tiene 58 años de edad,02 hijos y es casada, la socia alterna sus actividades diarias con el negocio de venta de ropa como casacas,chompas,polos entre otros, la socia lleva buen tiempo en este negocio el cual le va bien gracias al empeño que le pone cada día a su negocio, a la vez la socia es docente de profesión la socia enseña en uno de los colegios de la ciudad de Cusco , la socia desea poder seguir adelante con su negocio y trabajo para que de esta forma la socia continúe apoyando a su familia.

La socia solicita el crédito para la compra de mercadería como casacas.

Los demás socios se dedican a la venta de verduras, reparar celulares, restaurador, contadores y docentes.

La socia que sale en la foto adjunta pidió permiso para llegar tarde a la reunión por  motivos de trabajo.

La socia se siente agradecida por el crédito otorgado y se compromete a cumplir con sus cuotas establecidas.
texts.en:
Silvia is a member of the community bank "los inversionistas exitosos" [Successful Investors]. The bank is located in the district of Cusco and province of Cusco. 

Silvia is 58 years old, has two children, and is married. She mixes into her daily activities the business of selling clothes, like zip jackets, sweaters, polo shirts, and among other items. She has worked in this business for a good amount of time, which is going well thanks to the efforts that she puts forth every day toward her business. At the same time, she is a teacher by profession. She teaches in one of the schools in the city of Cusco. She hopes to be able to move forward with her business and work so that in this way she can continue to support the family. 

She is requesting this loan in order to purchase merchandise like zip jackets. 

The rest of the community bank members work selling vegetables, repairing cell phones, running a restaurant, as accountants, and as teachers. 

The member who is in the corner of the photo asked for permission to arrive late to the meeting for work reasons. 

Silvia is thankful for the loan and is committed to comply with her established payments.

loans.use: to purchase merchandise like zip jackets.

loans.name: Minerva

texts.en:
Minerva works hard to support her family. Minerva has a horticulture business in the Philippines.

Minerva requested a PHP 5,000 loan through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. (NWTF) to purchase additional equipment for her horticulture business like scissor, nail polish, knee-per, kneel cutter, etc.

Minerva has been in this business for five years now. She would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional equipment for her horticulture business like scissor, nail polish, knee-per, kneel cutter, etc.

loans.name: Manuel Concepcion

texts.es:
El socio Manuel se sigue dedicando al negocio de restaurant,el socio prepara desayunos,almuerzos y cenas,el socio tambien vende chicha de jora y frutillada,el socio ya tiene varios años en este negocio,el sueño del socio es ampliar el negocio de restaurant.El socio solicita el credito para compara arroz,pollo y verduras para el restaurant.

El socio se siente agradecido por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
This member is named Manuel and he continues to work in his restaurant business. He makes breakfasts, lunches and dinners. He also works selling chicha de jora and frutillada. He has had this business for several years and his dream is to expand the restaurant business. He is asking for the loan to buy rice, chicken and vegetables for the restaurant.

He is grateful for the loan and committed to making his payments.

loans.use: ro buy rice, chicken and vegetables for his restaurant.

loans.name: Jorge Asuncion

texts.es: Jorge de 36 años de edad vive en casa propia con su esposa y sus tres hijos de 9, 6 y 2 años de edad, el se dedica a la pesca artesanal desde hace varios años, tiene mucha clientela pues sus productos son bien frescos y a buen precio, con lo que obtiene de sus ventas logra solventar algunos gastos de su hogar, Jorge está solicitando un crédito para poder reparar  la lancha y comprar trasmallos  que utiliza para salir a pescar, ya que esa es su única fuente de trabajo y asi podrá darle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Jorge, 36, lives in his own house with his wife and their three children ages 9, 6 and 2. He has been working as a local fisherman for several years. He has many customers because his products are very fresh and at a good price. With what he obtains from his sales he manages to pay some household expenses. 

Jorge is requesting a loan to be able to repair his boat and to buy trammel nets which is used for fishing. This is his only source of income and thus it will be able to give him and his family a better quality of life.

loans.use: to repair his boat and to buy trammel nets.

loans.name: Sandra Del Socorro

texts.es:
La Señora Sandra del Socorro tiene un negocio de producción y venta de películas y discos musicales ubicado en el centro  de la ciudad de león desde hace 12  años, sale de su casa a las 7:00 am y abre su negocio a las 8:00 am cerrándolo a la 6:00 pm  siendo este trabajo el sustento de su familia.

La señora Sandra del Socorro solicita crédito a  CEPRODEL el cual utilizara este crédito para compra de materiales de construcción tales como: arena, cemento, bloqueos, hierro, etc., esto le permitirá poseer una mejor presentación en su centro de labores logrando el aumento de su cliente al igual que su cliente, el cual conllevara a mejorar sus ganancias y brindar una mejor calidad de vida a sus 6 hijos.
texts.en:
Sandra del Socorro has had a business making and selling movies and musical disks located in the center of the city of León for 12 years. She leaves her home at 7:00AM and opens her business at 8:00AM, closing it at 6:00PM. This work is the livelihood for her family.

Sandra del Socorro is asking for a loan from CEPRODEL which she will use to buy construction materials such as sand, cement, blocks, iron, etc. This will allow her to make a better presentation where she works building up her customers as clientele, which will take her towards better earnings and give a better quality of life to her six children.

loans.use: to buy blocks, cement, sand, and iron for improvements to her business

loans.name: Damazo

texts.en:
Damazo is 33 years old and lives in the town of Rukoki in the Masaka region of Uganda. He is Married  and has 4 children who are all currently in school. For the past 15 years, Damazo has been working hard to manage his clinic, which sells drugs. 

To help expand his business, Damazo has requested a loan of 3,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more drugs for his business, and will help Damazo to generate greater profits and to expand on the business. Damazo hopes that in the future he will be able to to expand more on the business. 

Damazo is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Damazo who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more drugs for his business

loans.name: Nyuma

texts.en:
Nyuma is grateful that he was able to secure his first loan from Kiva, and he was able to repay the loan. His business that has been running for more than ten years is growing, and he has decided to open another branch of her business in Mombasa town. 

The challenges in the business have been high fuel and transportation costs, and this has made him decide to open another shop closer to where the demand is. The extra income that he will raise will help him to introduce new product lines into his business.

loans.use: to open another branch of his business in Mombasa.

loans.name: Prisca

texts.en:
Prisca is 50 years old and she lives in the Likoni area, where she has a printing business that has been there for ten years. 

She is a married business lady with four children. She is also earns a salary, and she hopes that the business grows so that she can move to it full time. 

Prisca learned of Milango through friends, and now seeks a loan to buy printing material for her business.  

She wants to employ ten people in the next five years, despite the usual challenges of competition and inadequate materials. 

Prisca will use the extra income to improve her standard of living.

loans.use: to buy printing material

loans.name: Edridah

texts.en:
Edridah is 39 years old and lives in the town of Kasese in the Fort Portal region of Uganda. She is married and has 4 children who are all currently in school. For the past 10 years, Edridah has been working hard to manage her bar, which sells beer and sodas. 

To help expand her business, Edridah has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to increase the stock in the bar, and will help Edridah to generate greater profits and help in buying family necessities. Edridah hopes that in the future she will be able to add more stock. 

Edridah is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Edridah who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for micro-loans.

loans.use: to increase the stock in the bar.

loans.name: Living

texts.en: Living is 33-years-old and and a practicing farmer. He is married and has six children and of the six, four go to school. He started farming in 1998 with the hope of earning enough profits from the  farming business to educate his children. He does farming in kyamamari–nyanga Bitooma-Bushenyi District. His clients are mainly tea traders from the same locality. His main challenge is the weather which negatively changes and affects his garden and harvest. He says that despite the challenges that he has, he will remain the hard working farmer he has always been and if given the loan money (800000-eight hundred thousand shillings) he will use it to buy mulch for his garden.

loans.use: To buy mulches

loans.name: Nzokou

texts.fr: jean est un camerounais de 46 ans. père de 03 enfants dont le plus âgé 08 ans et le moins âgé 04 ans ( les 03 vont à l'école), Jean est cordonnier dans un quartier de la place depuis près de 08 ans. disposant d'une ponceuse vétuste, il souhaite avec l'argent du crédit acheter une nouvelle ponceuse et le cuir pour arranger les chaussures. les bénéfices seront réinvestis dans l'activité et lui permettront d'assurer le bien être de sa famille
texts.en:
Jean is a 46-year-old Cameroonian. father of three children, the eldest of whom is eight years old and the youngest four years (all three attend school),

Jean has been a shoemaker in the local neighborhood for nearly eight years. Saddled with a dilapidated sander, he will use the loan money to buy a new sander and leather to repair shoes with.

The profits will be reinvested in the business and also enable him to ensure his family's well-being.

loans.use: buy a sander and leather

loans.name: Ataobung Bazar Women Shg Group

texts.en:
Chaoton, age 45 years, is the featured borrower. She is pictured on the extreme left with her hand raised. Since six years ago, she has been making a living together with her husband by running a grocery shop just adjacent to her house.  With much less education and poor financial conditions, they had limited options to make a living. Before they switched to groceries, they have tried running a goldsmith shop, making jewelry, etc., but they cannot make a success out of it. A grocery business, where the profit is less but with high demand, makes it easier for them to continue successfully with the business. 

With information and references from a neighbouring (next to their shop) hotel that gets the benefit from WSDS, they learned about WSDS and their loans. So nine of them with similar interests to extend support to their family income joined together to make a group called the 'Ataobung Bazar Women SHG'.  

The group members have businesses like grocery, hotel and weaving.  With a promise to make the monthly return on time, they requested Kiva and WSDS sanction a loan so that they can expand their businesses and invest more in larger items on demand from time to time. Those with weaving businesses can buy the raw materials like yarns by themselves, without depending on others for the funds, and save the profit.

loans.use: to purchase grocery items for the shop and make more profit.

loans.name: Andro Bazar Shg Group

texts.en:
Mala, 31 years old and the featured borrower of the 'Andro Bazar SHG' on the extreme left with hand raised, did her best with the previous loan she received from WSDS. The loan helped her a lot in her brewery business, i.e., making  local wine, by enabling her to buy the raw materials like rice, yeast, charcoal, firewood and other necessities required from time to time. She also raised pigs which she feeds with the rice remaining after brewing. 

Mala and the other group members have successfully completed their first and second loan cycles. The loans helped Mala a lot in maintaining her family and covering household needs but she cannot expand much further to get more profits and savings as the price of commodities rises rapidly from time to time.  

Mala and the other group members are now asking for loan from KIVA. With the loan from KIVA, Mala expects to buy more rice, yeast, charcoal, firewood and piglets in larger quantity for expansion of her business to earn more profit, put aside savings and also make it easier for them in the repayment of the loan. Mala and the other group members expect a long association with WSDS and KIVA which they believe is an opportunity to bring a change in their lives.

The rest of the group members are engaged in weaving, piggery and brewery.

loans.use: To purchase a sack of rice, firewood and yeast in abundance to brew wine and make more income.

loans.name: Panam Shg Group

texts.en:
Ranjana and eleven other group members formed the 'Panam SHG' group. Ranjana, the featured borrower, is 35 years old. She is shown on the extreme left with her hand raised. 

Ranjana has a drug shop for animals at Andro bazaar. She also raises pigs at her house. She also keeps veterinary medicines, as there are no veterinary shops in her village. At times, she gives vaccinations and injections to pigs and dogs. She manages her business very well and also takes a keen interest in what she does. 

Most of the other members of the group brew wine, and some have shops. With the loan from Kiva and WSDS, she wants to expand her business by increasing the stock of her pharmacy. 

The other members who are brewers want to buy more rice, yeast, charcoal, firewood, etc. The others with the shops want to expand with more grocery stock. 

The group wishes WSDS and Kiva to grow and help people like them.

loans.use: to purchase more stock for her veterinary shop, so she can earn more income.

loans.name: Thel Shg Group

texts.en:
Tejmala, 54 years of age, is the featured borrower, on the extreme left in the photo with her hand raised. Eleven other group members with similar businesses together formed the 'Thel SHG'. Besides being a member of an economically backward family, the responsibility to take care of the children and provide education and other needs in a family with the rise in prices of every commodity in the market is not an easy task for Tejmala. The easiest way to make a living in the place she resides is by brewing local wine. Brewing wine and raising pigs are very profitable businesses as the rice that remains after brewing has been found to be very healthy for pigs. They don't need to buy it from elsewhere as they brew themselves and also extra expense is avoided to buy feed for the pigs.

With the loan from Kiva and WSDS, Tejmala wants to expand her business by buying more rice, yeast, charcoal, firewood and piglets. This will enable her to earn more profit and put aside savings and at the same time will make it easy for her to make the repayment of loans regularly and on time. 'Indeed getting a loan from WSDS and KIVA will be a blessing in disguise,' said Tejmala.

The rest of the group members are also engaged in brewing wine, piggery and weaving.

loans.use: To purchase rice, yeast, and firewood for brewing more wine and making more income.

loans.name: Sabina

texts.en:
Sabina is a 42-year-old married woman. She has 2 children with ages 5 years and 16 years. She sells cereals, i.e  maize, and beans to earn an income. She has been involved in this business for 5 years. Her business is located in a market and her primary customers are the locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be high transport costs.

Sabina will use the KES 20,000 loan to add stocks of maize and cow peas for resale. Her business goal is to have a wholesale business within 5 years. She hopes that in the future, she will be successful in business. This is her first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: buy maize and cow to sell

loans.name: Sunita

texts.en:
Sunita is 30 years old. She is Married and has one child, age 5. Many years ago, she established her cow milk selling business. Working seven days a week and four hours a day, she supports her family.

She has already received and successfully repaid three loans from Patan BPW, and used her most recent loan to buy a young milk-giving cow. In the future, Sunita plans to uplift the economic condition of her family. She thanks you for your support.
 
Dairy cows are an important source of nutrition and income in Nepal. Cows are never raised for beef, but for there milk from which curd (duy) and fresh cheese (paneer) are made. Jersey cows are the preferred breed for milking. On average, a dairy cow in Nepal will produce about 10 liters of milk each day.  In the local market, a liter of milk sells for about USD $0.50.
  
In addition to producing milk, cows provide dung that is used in home construction, as fuel for fires, and can be captured in methane storage tanks. The purchase of a dairy cow, made possible through a Kiva loan, is an investment that will repay itself many times over.

loans.use: to buy a young milk-giving cow.

loans.name: Josphine

texts.en:
Josphine is a 31-year-old married woman. She has one child who is 3 years old. She describes herself to be aggressive and a visionary. 

Josphine operates a cosmetics shop where she sells soap and other cosmetics. She has been involved in this business for 3 years. Her business is located in a local market and her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be high transport costs. She will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy materials to make soap. Her business goal is to be a large distributor of cosmetics within 5 years. She hopes that in the future, she will make a difference in society by helping alleviate poverty. This is her first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: buy materials to make soap

loans.name: Anahi

texts.es:
Anahi es comerciante, se dedica a la venta de celulares económicos de procedencia china los cuales los adquiere en la frontera, comercializándolos en una zona de la ciudad de La Paz donde se puede adquirir todo tipo de electrodomésticos, vive en la casa de sus padres en la ciudad de La Paz.
El crédito lo necesita para incrementar de su capital, adquiriendo nuevos modelos de celular y  de esta manera poder aumentar sus ingresos.

El sueño de Anahi es poder comprar su casa propia brindar a su familia mejores condiciones de vida.
texts.en:
Anahí’s a merchant.  She sells inexpensive Chinese-made mobile phones that she gets at the border and sells in a sector of La Paz where all sorts of electronic appliances can be found.  She lives in her parents’ house in the city of La Paz.

The loan she needs is to increase her capital acquiring new mobile phone models thus being able to increase her income.  Anahí’s dream is to be able to buy a house of her own to provide better living conditions for her family.

loans.use: to buy mobile phone supplies.

loans.name: Zozam Group

texts.en:
“Experience is the teacher of all things,” says Vahneu. It has been ages that she has been running a drug store in the suburban town market. Featured as the borrower member for the Zozam group and also pictured with her hand raised in the photograph, Vahneu believes in working hard and in loyalty. She is sincere and loyal in her work, as well as towards her group members. All of them reside in a village which is about 60 kms away from the main capital town of Manipur, which is also one of the Northeastern states in India.

Vahneu runs a drug store and generates income for the family. She usually gets the supplies from the district distributor agent at a subsidized rate and sells them at market price. The inefficiency and shortage of good doctors in the district hospitals cause the villagers to depend on drug stores for initial help. Vahneu’s drug store is well known in the neighbourhood for Vahneu’s skills to assist patients with vaccinations and in providing injections on site, which are a great help for the patients. 

The generated income is insufficient, as she has family expenses to bear. Her husband also earns by driving an auto rickshaw. In hard times, she used to borrow from money lenders with a high rate of interest to get the drug supplies for the store.

With the Kiva loan, she will purchase more drug supplies for the months to come. In a few months time, the festive season will start, in which they usually purchase items for the festival; these are expensive. She is glad that Kiva will help her purchase stock during this time. When she avails the loan, it will eventually help her in generating income and also to repay the loan on time. She says, “God bless Kiva.”

The rest of the group members are engaged in a cutlery shop, a variety shop, a dishwashing soap business, etc.

loans.use: to purchase more drug supplies for the pharmacy and generate more income.

loans.name: Mangalleima Women Group

texts.en:
“I am a weaver and this is the best I can do for a living to assist my husband financially in generating income for the family,” says Rojita, who is one of the members of Mangalleima Women SHG. She is pictured with her hand raised and is also the featured borrower for the group. 

Rojita's husband is a construction labourer and his source of income is unreliable and irregular. Work availability is the factor on which Rojita’s husband's income depends. She joined the Mangalleima Women's group to support herself with her weaving business and also to support other group members in need. All group members live in the same area which is about 40 kms away from the capital town of Manipur, and which is also one of the northeastern states in India.

Rojita weaves women's traditional wrap-around skirts using a loom. She usually gets the weaving materials like yarn and thread from the main market and weaves them. The finished woven products sell well during wedding seasons, as they are one of the main items a woman usually takes along to her in-laws house. The generated income is not sufficient to purchase weaving yarn and thread in abundance as she also shares the family's financial burden. 

To meet the demand of her customers, Rojita will purchase good quality yarn and thread with her Kiva loan and weave them. With the income she will open an account and start saving. She also says she will regularly repay the loan amount on time. She wishes to purchase a two-wheeler scooter for her husband so that he won’t be late for work and can efficiently perform his duty. She thanked Kiva and WSDS for the help and wishes to continue working under their sponsorship. She says, “Thank you, Kiva!”

The rest of the group members are also engaged in weaving, poultry, piggery and rice-selling businesses.

loans.use: To purchase good quality yarn and thread for weaving

loans.name: Dorcas Lom Group

texts.en:
“The reward of hard labour is life,” says 35-year-old Lhingkhochong. She also says, “no work, no life” as she and her husband are daily wage earners and their source of income is unreliable and irregular based, mainly on work availability and appropriate workload. She is the featured borrower for Dorcas Lom Group and she is pictured with her hand raised.  Her kids are in the capital town to study in good schools as the village does not have a good school. Her husband is a farmer and works in a paddy field. During off farming season, he usually sieves sand and digs underneath the riverbank for massive stones and sells them at a good price. It is completely manual work and takes a hard toil on the labourer. Deprived of all basic education, both Lhingkhochong and her husband work hard to manage the family expenses with all available work.

Lhingkhochong's main source of income is selling her own vegetable produce. She usually plants all seasonal vegetables and sell them after a period of four months, when the plants are fully grown. Her other income-generating activity is selling rice in the village and nearby villages. The rice supply is bought from the neighbouring state and sold in the town market and also in the village. The generated income is meager and can’t provide enough capital to start her livestock farming business, which had been her plan for quite a long time.

With the Kiva loan Lhingkhochong  plans to purchase two does and two bucks when she accesses the loan. Her plan is to rear the young goats while she is working in the fields and sell them when they mature. With the income she also aspires to start a charcoal business which is one of the highest demands in the area. It is non-seasonal and has no threat of expiration which is a very good option for generating income for them.

She thanked Kiva and WSDS for the wonderful support, enabling the group members to fulfill their desires and plans. She says she will always remain obliged and will also repay the loan on time. She also made a request that Kiva will continue helping them and hopes the co-operation will be a grand success. She says, "thank you so much, Kiva!”

The rest of the group members are also engaged in weaving, farming, selling vegetables, piggery etc.

loans.use: To purchase two does and two bucks, raise them, and sell them for a profit when fully grown.

loans.name: Star Group

texts.en:
“My strength lies is my hand axe, and without this, I would have begged on the roads,” says Lhingneichong. She is a woodcutter, and that is how she makes her livelihood for the family. She is pictured with her hand raised and is the featured borrower member of the group.

She and the other four women members formed the Star Group. The main motif of the formation of the group is to strengthen one another financially and socially. They believe that they will continue until the end. All of them live in the same village, which is about 65 kms from the capital town of Manipur, and which is also one of the northeastern states in India.

Lhingneichong sells charcoal in the village and nearby villages. She also supplies to other charcoal sellers in the town market and the capital market.  The wood is cut down from the forest and is turned into charcoal for selling. In order to get the wood supplies, she and her other partners contribute equal amounts of cash to rent the land for a period of one year. The land is usually shared by charcoal sellers, as the land is expensive for an individual to rent alone. Charcoal-selling is a good business, as it serves a number of purposes for different uses, and it is a non-seasonal product. 

With the Kiva loan, she will make a payment with the others for another plot of land for rent and will be ready for the next season. She is glad that she does not have to worry about the next season of making charcoal like before, when she used to get loans from money lenders at a high rate of interest. She is saved by Kiva and WSDS this season. 

She says, “Thank you so much, Kiva, and I will always remain grateful, and am looking forward to more help from Kiva.” The rest of the group members are also engaged in the charcoal business.

loans.use: to rent more land for firewood to use in making charcoal, and sell the charcoal to make more money.

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel is 53 years old, married and has 5 children.  He works as a solar lamp distributor in Mali.

Prior to becoming a distributor for NOTS, Daniel studied agriculture and engineering and worked as a farm manager at a Malian textile company.   Upon learning about the work of NOTS Mali, he was very motivated to become a distributor because he knew solar lamps would be a great benefit to people living in the rural areas where he lived and worked.  

Daniel sells solar lamps directly to farmers and through small retailers and individual entrepreneurs in Sikasso, the southern-most region in Mali.   Most people living in this area work in agriculture and about 80% of the population does not have access to electricity.  They rely, instead, on kerosene, flashlights and candles for light and they must walk long distances and pay to charge their mobile phones.  On top of being harmful to the environment, time-consuming, and damaging to users health (inhaling kerosene fumes is like smoking 2 packs of cigarettes a day), these energy sources are expensive, costing a family about $110 per year - $80 for kerosene and $30 to charge a mobile phone.   

A solar lamp that provides up to 16 hours of light, can charge a mobile phone and has a lifetime of about 5 years costs just $35.  Purchasing a solar lamp is a win-win - families benefit because they save time, money and they are safer and healthier and the environment benefits from less toxic waste and reduced CO2 emissions caused by kerosene use.  

The funds from Kiva investors will allow Daniel to purchase 570 solar lamps and sell them to cotton and sesame farmers on credit.  These lamps will impact almost 4,000 lives.  Harvest season starts in September, so it is a good time for Daniel to sell lamps as the farmers will have some money to pay for the lamps.  It is difficult, however, for them to pay in one lump-sum payment, so Daniel will collect payments in installments.  This way farmers can access solar light without so much financial strain on their household.

loans.use: To buy solar lamps that he will sell to cotton and sesame farmers.

loans.name: Keletie

texts.en:
This is 51-year-old Keletie. He is married, and has 4 children, ages 18, 15, 12 and 8. He has 1 additional dependent who lives with him for proper care. In 1993, Keletie established his spare parts business. He began his business just so he could support his children. His business is located at the city center and his main customers are mostly drivers. Working 7 days a week and 10 hours a day, he earns about Le 700,000 every month from this business. 

Keletie would like a loan in the amount of Le 5,000,000. He has already received and successfully repaid 3 loans, and now requires a new loan in order to buy clutch liner-1,000,000, Peugeot ball joints-1,000,000 and clutch kits-500,000. He hopes that this loan will expand his business. In the future, Keletie plans to build another house and to educate his kids. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more spare parts.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
This is 48-year-old Mary.  She is married, and has 3 children, ages 22, 20 and 19. In 2000, Mary established her palm oil and commercial bikes business. She began her business because she wants to help her husband take care of the home. Working 7 days a week and 14 hours a day, she earns about Le350,000 every month from this business. 

Mary would like a loan in the amount of Le4,000,000. She requires a loan in order to purchase more palm oil for resale. In the future, Mary plans to build a house. She is very hardworking. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more palm oil for resale.

loans.name: Samira

texts.en:
This is 32-year-old Samira. She is married, and has two children, ages 8 and 2 years old. In 2007, Samira established her Frozen Fish business. She began her business because she wanted to assist her husband in their home affairs. Working 7 days a week and 10 hours a day, she earns about SLL 1,000,000 every month from this business. 

She would like a loan in the amount of SLL 5,000,000. Samira requires the loan in order to buy more cartons of fish for resale. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits. In the future, Samira plans to get a cool room for herself so that she can make more profit. She is very hardworking.  

She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more cartons of fish for resale.

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David is 29 years old and lives in Mombasa, Kenya. He is a married businessman with two children. One of the children attends school. 

For the last six years David has been running a cereals business. He is a taxi driver himself and therefore he has employed someone to run the business on his behalf. He hopes that his business will grow big and he can be a supplier in the next five years. 

David knew Milango through friends and now seeks a loan to buy packing bags for cereals in his shop. The extra income that he will raise will improve his standards of living and pay school fees for his children.

loans.use: to buy packing bags for cereals

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica is a Kubo Financiero client and this is her story.

Hello my name is Monica, I am 40 years old and I have been working as a waitress in a restaurant for the last 8 years. In the restaurant I have a small salary both also get some good tips. When I am not working in the restaurant I also sell products by catalog, so by complementing both income sources I have been able to provide some financial stability for my daughters. I will use the loan for some required home improvements such as putting some tiles in the bathroom.

loans.use: to put some tiles in the bathroom of her house

loans.name: Richard T. J. Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are teachers from the township of Waterloo, in western Sierra Leone. This group of teachers has come to SMT, a partner of Kiva.org, to apply for a loan of 18,800,000 SLL for the entire team. With the help of this loan, they are going to meet their most immediate and most pressing financial needs. And at the end of each month, they can easily repay the loan using their monthly salaries. It is their school’s bursar who is directly responsible for doing the deductions and making the repayments on their behalf. 

Richard is the featured leader of this team of teachers. Richard was born in Moyamba district, in southern Sierra Leone. The 48-year-old is married to a school teacher and together they have 3 children who are attending primary and secondary schools respectively. Richard has been a school teacher for 21 years now. However, Richard is pursuing further studies in college. He has thus requested this loan in order to pay his college fees. 

(These borrowers came in two separate batches to collect the loan hence two sets of photos: one attached on top of the other).

loans.use: to pay his college fees

loans.name: Roselin

texts.en:
Roselin is a bonafide  resident of Diwan, Dipolog City, Philippines. She is 38 years of age, married and has four children. She and her husband work for their little store.

They have a good way of living and their business already exists for three years. They have daily sales of PHP 3,000.

She is applying for a loan to Paglaum MPC for additional capital of their store business. Roselin wanted to buy more stocks to sell like soap, canned goods, softdrinks and other basic commodities to sustain the needs of her customers.

This is her second loan availment from Paglaum MPC with no record of default.

loans.use: to buy some groceries to sell.

loans.name: Lorie

texts.en: Lorie is a businesswoman from Tuyabang Bajo, Oroquieta City. She is 31 years old, married and has a business of raising pigs. She has smoothly run this kind of business for years and is happy to take a loan from PMPC. Now, she is asking for a loan to purchase additional heads of pigs to raise. Lorie hopes to maintain her membership with PMPC.

loans.use: to purchase additional heads of pigs to raise.

loans.name: Rafaela

texts.en:
As a married parent of two children, Rafaela works hard to support her family.

She has a buy-and-sell purchase order card business in the Philippines and also earns additional income from a general store. Rafaela is borrowing PHP 15,000 through NWTF to purchase more purchase order cards to sell.

Rafaela has been sustaining her business activities through her past 12 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more purchase order cards to sell

loans.name: Therese

texts.fr: Therese est une femme de 39 ans mariée mère de 6 enfants dont l'age entre 2 et 21 ans. Elle est commerçante dans un marché de la capitale depuis 4 ans déjà. son activité c'est la vente des vivres frais(macabo, manioc,plantains)en fonction des saisons depuis 8 ans . Elle sollicite un nouveau crédit parce qu'elle aimerait acheter en grande quantité les régimes de plantains, sacs de macabo et de manioc dans les brousses pour venir revendre. Mais la petitesse de son capital ne lui permet pas de le faire, d'où la nécessité de ce crédit pour renforcer son activité.Ceci augmentera son capital, ses ventes et donc son bénéfice.Elle économisera ce bénéfice pour agrandir son activté et subvenir aux besoins de sa famille.
texts.en: Therese is a 39-year-old married mother of six children between the ages of 2 and 21 years old. She has been a trader in one of the capital city's markets for four years. She has been selling fresh produce (macabo, cassava, plantains) for eight years. She is looking to take out a new loan because she would like to buy bunches of plantains and sacks of macabo and cassava in bulk in order to re-sell them. But her limited capital restricts her from doing this, which is where the need for this loan to bolster her business comes in. This loan will increase capital, her sales, and thereby her profits. She will save her profits to grow her business and provide for her family.

loans.use: to buy a sack of cassavas, macabo and bunches of plantains

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en: Beatrice is a 28-year-old single business lady. She lives in the Mombasa area in Kenya. She started buying and selling ready-made clothes six months ago, and the business has been catching up. She knew Milango through friends and she decided to join so that she can be able to save and access funding for her business. Now she seeks a loan to buy more clothes for sale. She hopes that in five years time, the business will have grown into a whole business and she will be able concentrate on it fully. The challenge in the business is the competition. The extra income that she will raise will improve her standard of living.

loans.use: to buy more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Maryline

texts.en:
Maryline lives and works outside of Kitale town. Kitale is located in the Trans-Nzoia district of western Kenya. It is located close to Uganda and Mount Elgon, an extinct volcano which straddles the two nations and even has a peak at the Kenya-Uganda border. Founded by European settlers in the early 1900s, Kitale originally grew due to its proximity to the Ugandan railway. The area around Kitale is filled with natural forests, and maintenance of tree cover by the area’s residents has helped both preserve the region’s soil and ensured that the area remains good for beekeeping. Kitale is the headquarters of the Kenya Seed Company, whose massive sunflower plantations provide nearby bees with a veritable buffet of high-quality forage. 

Maryline is married, and has four children. Her husband works as a doctor, while Mary engages in projects on their land. She has been farming for ten years, and is currently growing maize, beans, bananas and tending to livestock. 

This is Maryline’s first loan, and she plans to use the income generated by her beehives to improve her farming. Her hope for the future is “to have a steady stream of income from my farm.”

loans.use: to buy beehives and apiary materials for honey production.

loans.name: Augustine

texts.en:
Augustine lives on a farm outside of Kitale town. Kitale is located in the Trans-Nzoia district of western Kenya. It is located close to Uganda, and Mount Elgon, an extinct volcano which straddles the two nations and even has a peak at the Kenya-Uganda border. Founded by European settlers in the early 1900s, Kitale originally grew due to its proximity to the Ugandan railway. The area around Kitale is filled with natural forests, and maintenance of tree cover by the area’s residents has helped both preserve the region’s soil and ensured that the area remains good for beekeeping. Kitale is the headquarters of the Kenya Seed Company, whose massive sunflower plantations provide nearby bees with a veritable buffet of high-quality forage. 

Augustine is married, and has seven children and many grandchildren. His wife has retired from teaching, and now they both farm their land. They have been farming for twenty years, and are currently growing beans, bananas and maize on their land, as well as rearing livestock and tending to natural forests. Augustine likes beekeeping because it is easy to practice, and is happy that the honey industry is being developed in his region. 

This is Augustine’s first loan, and he plans to use the income from his hives for household use. His hope for the future is “to see my grandchildren succeed in life.”

loans.use: to buy beehives and apiary materials for honey production.

loans.name: Abelina

texts.es: Abelina es muy joven, está casada con el señor Carlos y es mamá de cuatro niños los cuales asisten a la escuela. Ella y su familia viven en una comunidad muy tranquila, es una zona mazahua y sus habitantes son muy amables, siempre tratan de salir delante de alguna manera. Abe, como las personas de su comunidad la conocen, tiene un gran espíritu emprendedor: a sus  27 años tiene una papelería que lleva funcionando ya siete años. Abe platica que inició su tienda de abarrotes porque tenía necesidad de apoyar a a su esposo con los gastos del hogar y la educación de sus hijos; en primera instancia pensó en poner una tienda de abarrotes pero ya tenía mucha competencia. Entonces pensó en aprovechar el hecho de que había una escuale muy cerca de su casa y pensó que una papelería también sería un muy buen negocio. “Inicie vendiendo solo algunas libretas, colores, lápices, bolígrafos, sacapuntas, lo más indispensable, pero poco a poco vi muchas ganancias y cada vez los clientes me solicitaban más cosas de papeleria”. Explica que con créditos pequeños que la institución le ha hecho ha podido levantar su negocio poco a poco. Esta vez está solicitando un crédito para comprar una fotocopiadora, anteriormente no la había podido comprar precisamente por falta de dinero. Todos los días Abe abre desde muy temprano su papelería para atender a sus clientes, le gusta tener mucho contacto con sus clientes por eso siempre trata de darles los mejores precios. La meta de Abe es poder llenar un poco mas su papelería, ella considera que le hacen falta varias cosas y le gustaría seguir con su negocio porque es una muy buena manera de poder ayudar con los gastos del hogar; de lo contrario, si llega a cerrar su papelería tendría que salir a trabajar y descuidar a sus niños.
texts.en:
Abelina is very young.  She's married to Carlos and the mother of four children who attend school.  She and her family live in a very peaceful community.  It's a Mazahua area and the residents are very friendly and try to get ahead somehow.

Abe, as she's known in the community, has a great enterprising spirit.  At the age of 27 she has a school supplies store that she has had for seven years.

Abe says she started her store because she needed to help her husband with the household expenses and the children's education.  At first she thought about setting up a grocery store but there was a lot of competition.  Then she considered making the most of the school that was close to her house to start a school supplies store, which would also be a very good business.  "I started with only a few notebooks, colored pencils, pencils, pens, pencil sharpeners, the most essential things.  Little by little, though, I saw a lot of profit and the customers were always requesting more supplies."

Abelina says that she has been able to establish her business little by little with small loans from the institution.  Currently she's requesting a loan to buy a photocopier.  She couldn't buy one previously because she didn't have the money.

Abe opens her store very early every day to serve her customers.  She likes having a lot of contact with her customers and always tries to give them the best prices.

Abe's goal is to be able to stock her store a little more.  She thinks she needs a few things and would like to continue with her business because it's a very good way to help with the household expenses.  On the other hand, if she has to close her shop she would have to go out to work and would neglect her children.

loans.use: to buy a photocopier

location.town: Santa Cruz Mextepec, San Felipe del Progreso

loans.name: Edward

texts.en:
Edward is 22 years old and lives in the town of Seeta in the Mukono region of Uganda. He is married and has one child. For the past 10 years, Edward has been working hard to manage his retail shop, which sells music,phone accessories and video CDs. 

To help expand his business, Edward has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more phone accessories, empty CDs,Tapes to burn more music and movies to sell, and it will help Edward to generate greater profits and take good care of his parents. Edward hopes that in the future he will be able to expand his shop more. 

Edward is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Edward who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.


"

loans.use: to buy empty CDs to burn more music and movies to sell.

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James is 36 years old. He is a resident of Rubaga road ‘A’ Kampala city. He is divorced with one child who is attending school.
  
James deals in a business of brick laying located in a rural area in the city outskirts, which he started in 2002 with an aim of boosting his income. He got a loan of 2,000,000 Uganda shillings to rent more space where he can make more bricks in order to meet the high demand for the bricks. 
  
James sells mostly to all people from different towns; that is to say, some contracting entities, factories, schools and some individual constructors. However, his main challenge is inadequate capital to expand the business and seasonal changes like heavy rainfall, which affects the drying of the bricks. 

James is the kind of man who aims at having a determined and focused future by acquiring more money to boost his business so that it attains a steady growth.

loans.use: To hire land for making bricks.

loans.name: Dado's Group

texts.fr:
Le banc villageois nouvellement  inauguré ce 11 septembre 2013 est composé de  femmes ayant un vœu ardent d’intégrer le programme de bancs villageois. Elles entretiennent des relations de solidarité et d’entre aide mutuel et vivent toutes dans le même village depuis plusieurs années. Elles ont comme activité principale le petit commerce et la culture saisonnière sous pluie.

Madame DADO (assise à l’extrême droite en tunique rouge et noire), est l’emprunteuse vedette du groupe. Elle est mariée et mère de 07 enfants dont 04 filles et 03 garçons. Elle s’active dans la vente de miel. 
  
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elle s’approvisionner en galette  de miel dans les villages environnant, la presse pour recueillir le miel et la vendre.

Les bénéfices me permettent de renforcer son épargner pour obtenir durant les prochains cycles de prêts plus importants.
texts.en:
The newly-established Banc Villageois (created on 11th September 2013) is made up of women having a burning desire to join the Banc Villageois program. There is a great community spirit between them and a desire to help each other out;  they have all lived in the same village for several years and their principal activity is small-size trading and seasonal farming in the rain.

Dado (who is sitting on the far right of the photo in a red and black tunic) is the star borrower of the group. She is married and mother to seven children, four girls and three boys. She sells honey.

With this new loan she is going to get supplies of honeycomb from surrounding villages and a press for collecting the honey so she can sell it.

The profits will enable her to boost her savings so that she can get more significant loans during the following cycles.

loans.use: to get supplies of honeycomb from surrounding villages and a press for collecting the honey and selling it.

loans.name: Amy Cole's Group

texts.fr:
Ce banc villageois nouvellement  inauguré ce 12 septembre 2013, est composé de  femmes qui ont eu à mener des activités génératrice de revenus avant d’intégrer le programme de bancs villageois dans l’objectif d’accroître leur capacité de financement. Elles vivent toutes dans le même quartier depuis plusieurs années et entretiennent des relations de solidarité et d’entre aide mutuel. Elles ont comme activité principale le petit commerce. 

Madame Aissatou (debout à droite en tunique vert avec la main gauche  levée), est l’emprunteuse vedette du groupe. Elle est âgée de 35 ans, est mariée et mère de trois de filles de 02 à 08 ans. Son activité s’articule dans la vente de produits de cosmétiques et divers articles de beauté qu’elle achète soit dans la sous région et à la capitale pour revente dans sa localité à crédit ou au comptant selon sa relation avec la cliente. 

Avec ce nouveau prêt, elle compte renforcer sa capacité de financement en achetant 02 douzaines de lait de corps, une de shampoing et parfum par envoi.

 Les bénéfices obtenus lui permettront de participer d’avantage dans la gestion quotidienne des charges de la famille.
texts.en:
This banc villageois was recently inaugurated on 12 September 2013. It is made up of women who managed businesses and then decided to start a banc villageois program in order to expand their financial capacity.

They all have been living in the same area for several years and maintain relations of solidarity and mutual aid. They all engage in small-scale commerce.

Aissatou (standing on the right in the green dress with her left hand raised) is the featured borrower of the group. She is 35 years old, married, and a mother of three girls, who are from two to eight years old. 

She sells cosmetics and beauty products which she buys in the subregion and the capital and then resells in her area for credit or cash according to how she knows her customers. With this new loan, she plans to increase her financial capacity to buy two dozen [bottles] of lotion, shampoo, and perfume per shipment. 

Earnings will allow her to participate in the management of her family's everyday expenses.

loans.use: to buy two dozen bottles of lotion, shampoo, and perfume

loans.name: Ndeye's Group

texts.fr:
Ce groupe de 24 femmes fait parti du banc villageois qui a été crée le 12 décembre 2009. Il regroupe des femmes qui habitent dans le même village et ceux des alentours. Elles vivent une parfaite solidarité entre elles. 
Dibe âgée de 55 ans est mariée et mère de 2 enfants. Sur la photo elle est en position debout et a levé la main.
Avec le prêt elle va acheter 2 moutons à 30000f l'un et va assurer les frais vétérinaires et l’aliment de bétail qui lui revient à 67500f, les frais de convoyage des bêtes 2000f. Elle va les engraisser pour une durée de 5 mois.
Les bénéfices lui permettent d'épargner pour acheter un terrain, un projet qu'elle rêve de réaliser un jour.
texts.en:
This group of 24 women is part of the"banc villageois" that was founded on 12 December 2009. The group includes women who live in the same village and neighbouring villages. They all live in perfect solidarity.
Dibe is 55 years old- She is married and has two children. In the photo she is standing up with her hand raised.
She will use the loan to buy two sheep that cost 30,000 CFA each and she will cover the veterinary costs and livestock feed costs that come to 67,500 CFA, plus the transportation costs of the livestock for 2,000 CFA. She will fatten the sheep for a period of 5 months.
The profits will enable her to save so that she can buy a plot of land, a project that she dreams of being able to realize one day.

loans.use: To buy sheep

loans.name: Safiya Ali

texts.en: Safiya is 30 years old. She did not marry yet. Safiya graduated from the University of Hargeisa faculty of midwifery. Now she is getting her MBA in midwifery through distance learning. It is not possible to learn online without a computer and she cannot buy a laptop. She struggles with the fee of the University. She approached Kaaba MFI to get the laptop as a loan. Fortunately, Kaaba provided her with a laptop that she can pay for in installments. Now she can access the University website any time and she can download previous lessons and learn easily.

loans.use: To buy a laptop for educational purposes.

loans.name: Ilhan Ahmed

texts.en: Ilhan Ahmed is a 25-year-old single woman. She is a university student at  Alpha University College. Her problem is the lack of a laptop. She uses her friend's laptop during class presentations but it is very difficult for her when preparing assignments, as her friend is very far away. Kaaba provided her with a laptop that she can pay for in installments. Now she uses her laptop for any required activity in the university.

loans.use: To buy a laptop for educational purposes

loans.name: Mahmoud Biihi

texts.en: Mahamoud Biihi is a 26-year-old man. He is a university student and he studies at the University of Burao. Mahamoud is a single and not yet married. Buying a laptop on his own is the biggest challenge he faces in his learning process. Nowadays going to university without a laptop is like going to war with a gun without bullets. Lecturers use a projector during classes and give the students the soft copy of the lessons. Mahamoud took the laptop from Kaaba MFI as a loan and he will make monthly repayments.

loans.use: To buy a laptop for educational purposes

loans.name: Ayanle Abdirashid

texts.en: Ayanle is 18 years old. He studies human resource management and leadership at New Generation University College. He is a very cleaver student but his effort is reduced by the lack of a laptop, as he misses assignment deadlines and sometimes class presentations. He thanks Kiva and KAABA who enabled him to get the laptop loan. He will pay the loan in monthly installments. Ayanle hopes to work as an HR manger for a local NGO.

loans.use: To buy a laptop for educational purposes

loans.name: Hibaq Abdalle

texts.en: Hibaq is 22 years old and single. She studies at Adisababa Medical University College Faculty of Nursing. She needs a laptop to read her lessons, prepare assignments, and use university wireless to search for books and video tutorials. Kaaba provided her with a laptop that she can pay for in installments. After finishing the university, Hibaq hopes to work as a Hargeisa Hospital nurse.

loans.use: To buy a laptop for educational purposes

loans.name: Asia Abdi

texts.en: Asia Abdi is 16 years old. She studies at Blooming Secondary school. Asia needs a laptop loan. She wants to use the laptop for her school lessons. Paying the money all at one time is difficult for her, so Kaaba provided her with a laptop that she can pay for in installments. After secondary school she wants to use the laptop at university.

loans.use: To buy a laptop for educational purposes

loans.name: Jibril Ahmed

texts.en: Jibril Ahmed is 27 years old. He finished Nairobi University. Jibril is a teacher of young Muslim academics in Hargeisa town. His main challenge is that he has no laptop. He needs the laptop to prepare school lessons, exams, exercises, and to store student grades. Kaaba provided him with a laptop that he can pay for in monthly installments.

loans.use: To buy a laptop for educational purposes

loans.name: Ahmedwali Hassan

texts.en: Ahmedwali Hassan is 23 years old. He studies at Gollis unversity. He faces a major problem in both his learning and teaching. His problem is the lack of a laptop to learn and to teach. He came to Kaaba MFI to lend him a laptop and finally, Kaaba provided him with a laptop that he can pay for in monthly installments. After finishing his university, Ahmedwali hopes to work as a secondary teacher.

loans.use: To buy a laptop for educational purposes

loans.name: Aden Mahmoud

texts.en: Aden Mahmoud is 26 years old. He is married but does not yet have children. He finished Newcastle University in Khartoum, Sudan. Aden is now a secondary school teacher. He needs a laptop to prepare school lessons and he cannot pay the money all at one time. His good news was when he got the Kaaba-Kiva laptop loan. He approached Kaaba MFI and then Kaaba provided him with a laptop that he can pay for in installments. Aden hopes to improve his teaching as he has the laptop.

loans.use: To buy a laptop for educational purposes

loans.name: Mohamed Ali

texts.en:
Mohamed is 27 years old. He studies at Admas University College, faculty of development study. 

Being without a laptop is his major problem. He needs a laptop to prepare his assignments, download books and to make class presentations. Mohamed goes to an Internet café each week, and he spends more money to get access to the Internet. 

A laptop from Kaaba Microfinance Institution helped him to solve the above-mentioned problem.

loans.use: to buy a laptop for education purposes.

loans.name: Hashim Mohamed

texts.en:
Hashim Mohamed is 18 years old. He studies at Adna University College, faculty of medicine. 

His main challenge is the lack of a laptop, which he can't buy on his own. Kaaba provided him with a laptop that he can pay for in monthly installments.

After university, Hashim hopes to work as a doctors’ assistant at Adna Maternity Hospital.

loans.use: to buy a laptop for education purposes.

loans.name: Abdirisaq Ibrahim

texts.en:
Abdirisaq Ibrahim is 20 years old. He studies at the Islamic institute. 

He needs a laptop to enhance his learning. He learns using online courses, and he can't buy a laptop. Kaaba provided him with a laptop that he can pay for in monthly installments. 

Abdirisaq hopes to be a teacher at the Institute.

loans.use: to buy a laptop for education purposes.

loans.name: Sabah Osman

texts.en:
Sabah Osman is 30 years old. She is a university student. 

She faces a big problem in her learning, as she has no laptop to prepare her assignments and to read soft copies of her lessons. Kaaba Microfinance Institution provided a laptop, which Sabah can pay for in monthly installments. 

After university, Sabah hopes to work as a primary teacher.

loans.use: to buy a laptop for education purposes.

loans.name: Yusuf Farah

texts.en:
Yusuf Farah is 24 years old. He finished secondary school this year. 

He wants to start at university, and he has no laptop, so he wanted to utilize a Kaaba-Kiva laptop. Then Kaaba Microfinance provided him with the laptop, which he will pay for in monthly repayments. 

Yusuf hopes to work as accountant. He wants to prepare to be an accountant at his university.

loans.use: to buy a laptop for education purposes.

loans.name: Asma Jibril

texts.en:
Asma Jibril is 23 years old. She studies at Gollis University College, faculty of medicine. She is a senior student and preparing her graduation research paper.

Her main challenge is the lack of a laptop to prepare the thesis book. She approached Kaaba Microfinance Institution for a laptop. Kaaba provided the laptop, which she can pay for in monthly repayments. 

After finishing university, Asma wants to work as a nurse.

loans.use: to buy a laptop for education purposes.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is a repeat borrower aged 52 years old. She is a resident of Nkongoro, Ntungamo District. She is a married with six children.

Jane applied for a loan of UGX 2,500,000 to improve her cattle business. She has a challenge of low business turnover due to few purchases and low consumption of milk. She decided to come to UGAFODE for a loan to buy milk cans so that she can expand her milk production business, improve her well-being and pay tuition for her children.

loans.use: to buy milking cans and milk storage cans.

loans.name: Jose Marcel

texts.es: Marcel de 37 años de edad, habita en una comarca cercana a Managua en casa de sus padres a quienes apoya económicamente, Marcel se dedica a brindar servicios de bufette para eventos especiales, compra cerdos, pelibuey y los destaza para hacer comidas variadas y venderlos. Solicita el crédito para comprar cerdos, pelibuey, carbón y condimentos, para continuar brindando sus servicios a sus clientes.
texts.en: Marcel, 37, lives in a neighborhood near Managua with his parents, who he supports economically. Marcel works providing buffet services for special events. He buys pigs and Pelibüey sheep and then butchers them to make assorted dishes and sell them. He is asking for the loan to buy pigs, Pelibüey sheep, charcoal, and condiments in order to continue providing his services to customers.

loans.use: to buy pigs, Pelibüey sheep, charcoal, and condiments

loans.name: Sofia

texts.en:
Sofia is a 57 years old green grocer and cereal seller. She is married to Njeru, and together they are blessed with two sons. Sofia has been running her grocery and cereal store for the past five years with a monthly income of KES 5,000, which she uses to support her family. 

Sofia is applying for her second loan term with KADET. She will use the loan to purchase more beans, maize, ground nuts, bananas to stock her business for more profits. 

With the anticipated profit from the business. she will pay her loan and pay school fees for her children. 

Her hopes and dreams are to improve the living standards of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more beans, maize, ground nuts and bananas for resale

loans.name: Alfred

texts.en:
Alfred lives on a farm outside of Kakamega town, in Kakamega county. Kakamega county is located in Western Kenya and is famous for its rain forest. Many farmers in the area grow maize, sugar cane and bananas, with maize being the primary crop. The density of the old growth trees in the Kakamega forest, and the variety of crops grown in the area, make this an excellent area for beekeeping. 

Alfred is married, and has four children. Both Alfred and his wife have been farming for fifty years, and are currently growing maize, beans and vegetables on their land. Alfred likes beekeeping because despite the fact that he does not have a big farm, he can still keep bees, because they use very little land. This is Alfred’s first loan with Kiva, and he plans to use the income from his hives to buy a dairy cow. Alfred’s hope for the future is to buy more land to do farming.

loans.use: to buy beehives for honey production.

loans.name: Laura

texts.en:
Laura lives on a farm outside of Kakamega town, in Kakamega county. Kakamega county is located in Western Kenya and is famous for its rain forest. Many farmers in the area grow maize, sugar cane and bananas, with maize being the primary crop. The density of the old growth trees in the Kakamega forest, and the variety of crops grown in the area, make this an excellent area for beekeeping. 

Laura is married, and has three children. Her husband works as a watchman, while she runs a small business. When not busy with their jobs, both her and her husband farm their land. They have been farming for twenty years, and are currently growing maize and beans as well as rearing a cow. This is Laura’s first loan with Kiva, and she plans to use the income from her hives to expand her small business. In the future, she hopes to “be a successful farmer and business lady.”

loans.use: to buy beehives for honey production.

loans.name: Apollo

texts.en:
Apollo lives Kagyera, Western Division – Rukungiri Municipality. He is married with three children and is an old client at the institution who is applying for a loan of 1,500,000 UGX. He is a secondary school teacher and also practices agriculture where he earns additional income. The purpose of this loan is to finish his house which he has been building using the previous loans obtained from UGAFODE Microfinance Limited (MDI) and his salary.

Apollo is a hardworking and honest man but he is always limited by working capital, that’s the reason he is applying for this loan.

His major challenges have been school fees and housing facilities but he is hopeful that with this loan, he will finish his house and save the money that he has been paying in rent to use for other projects.

loans.use: To buy housing materials

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose lives in the Eldoret area of Kenya, which is extremely fertile for agriculture. She has three children, and has been doing this work for 22 years. Her primary income sources are milk, eggs, crops, and personal business.

She stated what is most enjoyable about farming is 'Being able to get food and income from agriculture to meet family needs'. Her biggest challenge is 'poor roads during the rainy season makes it costly to transport products to the market, and the fluctuation of weather patterns makes agribusiness unpredictable.' Animals on the farm have not been given names.

Rose was asked why she chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which she replied, 'Chose Juhudi Kilimo following the success of another group member in the Juhudi Kilimo group.' This client was also asked what was learned during Juhudi's required microfinance training session 'Learned how I could access financial services to acquire agricultural asset to boost family income.'

Her highest monthly expense is business related. When asked 'How will this loan benefit her family', Rose replied 'Will purchase water tank and start a poultry project.'

As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Rose owns the following: 'cow, poultry' but does not own 'pig, pump, bicycle, motorcycle, automobile'. Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household 'mosquito net' but does not have 'electricity, solar power, running water, sewing machine, TV, DVD'.

loans.use: To purchase poultry and a water tank.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary lives in the Kisii area of Kenya, which is not far from Masai land. She has five children. Her primary income sources are milk, eggs, tea, and crops; she has been doing this work for four years.

She stated that what she most enjoys about farming is the "income received from it." Her biggest challenge is that she "needs more time." Animals on the farm have been given the names of "Juhudi."

Mary was asked why she chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which she replied, "Low interest." This client was also asked what was learned during Juhudi's required microfinance training session: "Help people to improve life."

Her highest monthly expense is school fees. When asked how this loan will benefit her family, Mary replied, "It will improve their livelihood."

As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Mary owns the following: cow, poultry. She does not own pig, pump, bicycle, motorcycle, or automobile. Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household mosquito net and solar power, but does not have electricity, running water, sewing machine, TV, or DVD.

loans.use: to purchase a dairy cow and a water tank.

loans.name: Korotoumou

texts.en:
AVEC-Mali is a women’s association based in Mopti, Mali. Association members are engaged in a variety of activities, such as selling improved cook stoves, teaching reading and writing to women’s groups, and educating women in their community about family planning.

Korotoumou is one of nine members of AVEC-Mali who sell solar lamps. She is 47 years old and has six children. In addition to her work with the women’s association, Korotoumou is the matron at a health center in Mopti, and she sells grains. In July, she started selling solar lamps to fisherman, students and farmers, who are reliant on kerosene and flashlights for light. With a solar lamp, her customers can save money. Kerosene and mobile phone charging currently cost about $110 per year; whereas, a solar lamp costs $25 and has a lifetime of about five years. These solar lamps can provide up to 16 hours of light and can charge a mobile phone.

On top of being less expensive, solar lamps are more durable and reliable and keep people from stealing mobile phones. “With a solar lamp, you don’t have to go to a mobile phone charging station and give your phone to someone who may steal your phone or use the call credit you have on your phone,” says Korotoumou.

On top of benefiting consumers, selling solar lamps provides income for the women and for the association, AVEC-Mali. The women earn about $2 per lamp that they sell, and the association earns $3, which is then invested in a warehouse to store solar lamp inventory and motorcycles to distribute the products.

The solar saleswomen are well organized – each responsible for her own sales territory. They educate their communities about the benefits of solar lights and generate lamp sales through group meetings and demonstrations at night.

Since paying for the lamps up front is simply too expensive, the women need working capital. A Kiva loan will allow the group to obtain solar lamp inventory from NOTS Lampe Solaire and pay for it in installments.

loans.use: to buy solar lamp inventory that they will sell in their communities.

loans.name: Mwanarusi

texts.en:
Mwanarusi has operated a fruits and vegetables selling business. She sells to her neighbors and passersby. Her major challenges are high cost of transportation to her place of operation.The previous loan helped her buy tomatoes, potatoes, onions and vegetables for sale to her customers, and she appreciated the help.

With the KES 25,000, she wants to purchase sacks of fruits and various vegetables to add to the stock for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business and improve her living standards.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of fruits and various vegetables for resale.

loans.name: María Eugenia

texts.es:
María Eugenia es una señora de 43 años originaria del municipio de El Sauce, un poblado ubicado al occidente de León, madre de soltera de tres hijos dos de ellos a su cargo uno que estudia en la universidad y el otro en la secundaria.
Con su salario de maestra ha hecho el esfuerzo por tener a sus hijos estudiando, ya que su gran reto es que sean profesionales.
Ella imparte clases de consejería a los niños de primaria en un colegio de la localidad dese hace doce años.
María Eugenia está solicitando un crédito a los inversionistas de Kiva para que a través de Ceprodel le financien dicho crédito para pagar los gastos universitarios de su hijo y el pasaje de un viaje ya que está estudiando una carrera profesional fuera del  país y esta de vacaciones por aquí Nicaragua.

A pesar de que está becado ella como madre responsable tiene que costear el pasaje de ida y regreso y algunos gastos de la universidad.
Tiene la esperanza en Dios y en estas personas que apoyen su solicitud para poder enviar a su hijo a esta universidad.
texts.en:
María Eugenia is a 43-year-old woman who comes from the municipality of El Sauce, a settlement located west of León. She is the single mother of three children. Two of them are her dependents, one studying at university and the other in secondary school. 

With her salary as a teacher, she has made the effort to have her children attend university, since her great goal is to see them become professionals. 

For the past twelve years, she has given council classes to the primary-grade children at a school in her area. 

María Eugenia is requesting a loan from the Kiva lenders so that they will finance this loan through Ceprodel to pay her son's university expenses and his travel to Cuba, since he is studying for a professional degree in that country, and he is currently spending his vacation here in Nicaragua. 

Although he is on scholarship, she as the responsible parent has to pay for his round-trip travel and for some university costs. 

She "has faith in God and in the people who support her request so that she can send her son to this university."

loans.use: to pay university costs and travel for her son.

loans.name: Everline

texts.en: Everline is a 25-year-old single mother. Upon finishing school she found it difficult to find stable work, was unemployed for long periods at a time, and held odd jobs that paid low wages.  She is ambitious and determined.  She enjoys selling energy-efficient products like fuel-efficient cook stoves and solar lighting products in slums around Nairobi through the iSmart distribution network, as she knows these products help to improve lives.  Her biggest challenge is not having enough capital to buy enough products to sell.  She will use the $1000 loan to buy more stoves and solar lamps to sell, as well as an agent toolkit that includes a uniform and tools that will help her business.

loans.use: To purchase products to sell to customers

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy flour and sugar to bake bread.

loans.name: Maria Antonia

texts.es:
María, vive con en una casa familiar, tiene una hija de 11 años que asiste a la escuela. Solicita un crédito para mejorar su negocio de venta de tamales, ropa también se  dedica a la agricultura. Ella emprendió por cuenta propia su negocio desde hace seis años; quiere hacerlo crecer por lo que solicita un préstamo para compra de ropa nueva de estilos diferentes, abono, y herbicida.
Su sueño es generar más ingresos para mejorar la calidad de vida que tiene su familia y de esta forma también brindar el apoyo necesario a su hija para su superación educativa.
texts.en: Maria lives in her family home and has an 11-year-old daughter who is in school.  She requests a loan to improve her business selling tamales and clothes.  She also works in agriculture.  Maria started her own business six years ago.  She wants to grow her business so she is requesting a loan to buy new clothes in different styles, fertilizer, and herbicide.  Her dream is to increase her income in order to improve her family's quality of life and also provide her daughter with the support she needs to be successful in school.

loans.use: to buy new clothes in different styles, fertilizer, and herbicide.

loans.name: Ramadhan

texts.en:
Ramadhan is 31 years old, married, and blessed with two children. Ramadhan also supports and takes care of his aging grandmother. He runs a bakery, which has been in operation for some years, with a monthly income of KES 9,000.

He is borrowing a loan of KES 30,000, which he plans to use to boost his business by making more cakes and bread for sale. He will purchase more baking flour for the cakes. This is his first loan and his dreams and hopes are to be successful.

loans.use: to purchase more baking flour for the cakes to boost his business by making more cakes for re-sale.

loans.name: Domitila

texts.en: Domitila is a 33-year-old married woman. She has three children with ages ranging from 6 years to 12 years. She describes herself to be social. She operates a salon where she offers hair dressing services. She has been involved in this business for 12 years. Her primary customers are ladies. She describes her biggest business challenge to be power outages which affect her business. She will use the 20,000 KES loan to buy hair chemicals and hair weaves. Her business goal is to expand within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will own her own home. This is her first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: to buy hair chemicals and hair weaves.

loans.name: Kadiatou's Group

texts.fr:
Ce banc villageois Nouvellement inauguré, ce 26 septembre 2013 est composé de femmes très dynamiques, elles désirent apporter un changement dans leurs conditions d’existence raison pour la quelle elles ont intégré le programme des bancs villageois.
