Elles vivent dans un même village depuis plusieurs décennies et entretiennent des relations de solidarité et d’entre aide. Elles ont comme activité principale le petit commerce accompagné de la culture sous pluie. 

Madame Kadiatou, âgée de 35 ans (debout à l’extrême droite), est l’emprunteuse vedette du groupe. Elle est mariée et mère d’un garçon. C’est une femme très engagée dans les activités du groupement et s’active dans la vente de produits alimentaires tels que le sucre, le thé vert, les assaisonnements et bouillons en gros ou demi gros pour la revente par détail.

Avec son nouveau prêt, elle prévoit d’acheter en 03 à 05 sacs d’ognons et un carton de thé vert pour la revente lors des fêtes de Tabaski.

Les bénéfices lui  permettront de soutenir son mari dans la gestion des dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
This newly inaugurated "banc villageois", created on 26th September 2013, is made up of dynamic women wishing to bring about change in their living conditions. It is for this reason that they started up this "banc villageois". They have been living in the same village for several decades. They support each other through collectivism and mutual assistance. Their main source of income is a whatever business they can find in this struggling country.

35-year-old Kadiatou (the woman sitting the furthest to the right in the photo) is this group's star entrepreneur. She is a married mother of one son.

She is very active in the group's business. She takes part in the purchasing of foodstuffs such as sugar, green tea, herbs and spices and bouillon in bulk for retail sale.

With this new loan, she wants to buy three to five sacks of onions and a carton of green tea for resale during the Tabaski celebrations.

The profits will allow her to support her husband with the daily household expenses.

loans.use: to buy three to five sacks of onions and a carton of green tea for resale during the Tabaski celebrations

loans.name: Javier Abdul

texts.es:
Javier, tuvo un efecto positivo con su crédito anterior; tuvo una cosecha más abundante y mejores ingresos, por lo que hoy solicita un nuevo préstamo para comprar abono, insecticidas, semilla y la preparación de la tierra para la siembra de plátano y maíz.
Ha logrado mantenerse activo en su actividad económica, cubrió parte de las necesidades de su familia. Anhela seguir aumentando las cosechas para cumplir con sus compromisos.
texts.en:
Javier's previous loan had a positive effect giving him an abundant harvest and more income.  Therefore, he is requesting a new loan to buy fertilizer, insecticides, and seed and to prepare the land to plant bananas and corn.

He has been able to stay in business and cover his family's needs.  He wants to continue increasing his production in order to meet his commitments.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, insecticides and seeds.

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine lives in the Kitale area of Kenya, which lies in the northern part of the Rift Valley. She has 4 children and has been doing this work for 6 years. Her primary income sources are milk, crops, and personal business.

She stated what is most enjoyable about farming: 'it's the source of income for the family.' Her biggest challenge is 'Drought.' Animals on the farm have been given the names of 'Maua.'

Christine was asked why she chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which she replied: 'Listens to clients.' This client was also asked what was learned during Juhudi's required micro-finance training session: 'They go out to reach of the clients.'

Her highest monthly expenses are family expenses. When asked: 'How will this loan benefit her family', Christine replied: 'Help in paying school fees.'

As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Christine owns the following: 'cow and poultry,' but does not own 'pig, pump, bicycle, motorcycle, or automobile'. Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household: 'mosquito net and running water,' but does not have 'electricity, solar power, sewing machine, TV, or DVD'.

loans.use: to purchase poultry.

loans.name: Royasi

texts.en:
Royasi is 38 years old and lives in the town of Makidye in the Kampala south region of Uganda. He is married and has two children with one of them currently in school.For the past five years, Royasi has been working hard to manage his retail shop, which sales house hold items. 

To help expand his business, Royasi has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more items for the shop such as utensils to sell, and will help Royasi to generate greater profits and provide more necessities for his family. Royasi hopes that in the future he will be able to construct rental houses. 

Royasi is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Royasi who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more items for the shop such as sugar, salt and bread to sell.

loans.name: Vascolina

texts.en:
Vascolina lives in the Nkubu area of Kenya. She has 2 children. Her primary income sources are milk and crops.  In addition to farming, she has a retail business as an extra source of income. She has been doing this work for 10 years.  

Vascolina stated that what is most enjoyable about farming is "profits earned." and that her biggest challenge is "poor markets." Animals on the farm have been given the names of "Kamau."

Vascolina was asked why she chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which she replied, "'Low interest rates."  This client was also asked what was learned during Juhudi Kilimo's required micro-finance training session and she stated, "Savings are used as collateral."

Her highest monthly expense is family expenses. When asked how will this loan benefit her family, Vascolina replied, "Help raise school fees."

As part of Juhudi Kilimo's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Vascolina owns a cow, a pig, and poultry, but does not own a pump, a bicycle, a motorcycle, or an automobile. Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household a mosquito net, electricity, a TV, and a DVD player, but does not have solar power, running water, or a sewing machine.

loans.use: to start an Agrovet business.

loans.name: Fredrick

texts.en:
Fredrick is 52 years old and lives in the town of Luwero in the Luwero region of Uganda. He is married and has six children with two of them currently in school. For the past four years, Fredrick has been working hard to manage his retail shop, which sells bicycle spare parts. 

To help expand his business, Fredrick has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to stock more bicycle tubes and other items to sell, and will help Fredrick to generate greater profits and pay school fees for his children. Fredrick hopes that in the future he will be able to put up another branch of the same business. 

Fredrick is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Fredrick who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to stock more bicycle tubes and other items to sell

loans.name: 01.08.01 Đông Sơn Group

texts.en:
Liên operates a food stall/restaurant selling soup. She is requesting a loan to purchase materials to make the processed food to sell.

Liên is 51 years old and she is married with one child. She is the group leader of the 01.08.01 Đông Sơn solidarity group, which consists of six members. 
Liên lives with no dependents in Thanh Hoa city, an urban town in Thanh Hoa province. Her children are grown up.

In 2012, Liên joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her business. She has successfully repaid three loans from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Liên has been involved in this business for five years. The main hardship that she faces in her business is the lack of capital.

With her business profit, Liên hopes for her business to do well, for her family to be healthy and happy, and to remodel her house.

loans.use: to purchase materials to make processed food for retail

loans.name: Thomas

texts.en:
Thomas lives in the Kisii area of Kenya, which is scarce of available land. He has 3 children, and has been doing this work for 12 years. His primary income sources are eggs, crops, and personal business.

He stated what is most enjoyable about farming: 'The yield and income.' His biggest challenge is: 'Lack of enough capital.' Animals on the farm have been given the name of 'Nyeusi.'

Thomas was asked why he chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which he replied: 'Good customer care and service delivery.' This client was also asked what was learned during Juhudi's required micro-finance training session: 'How to save.'

His highest monthly expenses are farming costs. When asked: 'How will this loan benefit his family', Thomas replied: 'Improve our lives.'

As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Thomas owns the following: 'cow and poultry,' but does not own 'pig, pump, bicycle, motorcycle, or automobile'. Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household 'mosquito net,' but does not have 'electricity, solar power, running water, sewing machine, TV, or DVD'.

loans.use: to purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David lives in the Kisii area of Kenya, which is not far from Masai land. He has eight children and has been doing this work for 30 years. His primary income sources are milk, eggs, tea and crops.

He stated what is most enjoyable about farming: "Mixed farming," because he gets enough food surplus for his family and income. His biggest challenge is a "lack of market." Animals on the farm have been given the names of Maritati and Nyeusi.

David was asked why he chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which he replied that it helps small farmers like him. This client was also asked what was learned during Juhudi's required micro-finance training session: "Not to divert funds."

His highest monthly expense is school fees. When asked how this loan will benefit his family, David replied, "Improve their lives."

As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. David owns the following: cow and poultry, but does not own a pig,  pump, bicycle, motorcycle or automobile. Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household mosquito net, solar power, TV and DVD, but does not have electricity, running water or a sewing machine.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is 46 years old and lives in the town of Masindi, in the Hoima region of Uganda. She is married and has six children, four of them currently in school. For the past five years, Grace has been working hard to manage her piggery farm,which sales pigs. 

To help expand her business, Grace has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more piglets to sale. This will help Grace to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children. Grace hopes that in the future, she will be able to expand the business into a bigger one, by creating more space for more pigs. 

Grace is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Grace, who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more piglets to sale.

loans.name: Avec-Mali

texts.en:
AVEC-Mali is a women’s association based in Mopti, Mali with 74 members. The association engages in a variety of activities, such as selling clean cookstoves, teaching women to read and write and educating women about family planning.  

In July, nine women from the association starting selling solar lamps (seven of them are featured in the photo).  As of the end of September they sold 1,200 lamps and they have ambitious plans to grow the sales. 

Korotoumou (fourth from the left) is one of nine members of AVEC-Mali who sell solar lamps. She is 47 years old and has six children. In addition to her work with the women’s association, Korotoumou is the matron at a health center in Mopti, and she sells grains.  In July, she started selling solar lamps to fisherman, students and farmers, who are reliant on kerosene and flashlights for light.  With a solar lamp, her customers can save money.  Kerosene and mobile phone charging currently cost about $110 per year; whereas, a solar lamp costs $25 and has a lifetime of about five years.  These solar lamps provide 8 hours of light and can charge a mobile phone.

On top of being less expensive, solar lamps are more durable and reliable and keep people from stealing mobile phones. “With a solar lamp, you don’t have to go to a mobile phone charging station and give your phone to someone who may steal your phone or use the call credit you have on your phone,” says Korotoumou.

Selling solar lamps provides income for the women and for the association. The women earn $2 for every lamp they sell and the association earns $3.  The money the association earns is invested in a warehouse to store solar lamp inventory and motorcycles to distribute the products.

The solar saleswomen are well organized – each responsible for her own sales territory. They educate their communities about the benefits of solar lights and generate lamp sales through group meetings and demonstrations at night.

Since customers cannot afford to pay for the lamps up front, the women need working capital. A Kiva loan will allow the solar saleswomen to obtain solar lamp inventory from NOTS Lampe Solaire on credit and then extend credit to their customers.

loans.use: to buy solar lamp inventory that they will sell in their communities.

loans.name: Baya

texts.en:
Baya is a 26-year-old widow. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family and fees for her two children.

For the past three years, she has operated a small shop business, selling consumable goods from home to local neighbors. She dreams of expanding to a big shop in the future. 

With the KSHS 25,000, she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, rice, maize flour and sugar to sell. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour, rice, maize flour and sugar to sell.

loans.name: Fred

texts.en:
Fred is a married man with four children. He will use the loan to pay tuition fees for his children who are supposed to register for the first year at university. 

He is grateful that Kiva through Ugafode, is willing to bail him out in his time of need. He is hard working and innovative. He will use money from milk sales to repay the loan.

loans.use: to pay tuition fees for his children.

loans.name: Amy's Group

texts.fr:
Ce groupe a été créé depuis 2011.Il est composé de membres qui habitent le même village,elles ont comme activité principale le petit commerce,l'agriculture.

Celle qui se trouve à l'extrême droite de la photo et levant le bras,est la responsable du groupe,elle est mariée ,est âgée de 41 ans et mére de 06 enfants.

Sa principale activité est la restauration ,elle tient un petit restaurant où elle vend du petit déjeuné.Elle fait cette activité depuis plus de 10 ans,ce qui fait qu'elle a pu fidéliser un nombre important de clients.

Avec le prêt reçu,elle compte acheter 10 caisses d’œuf pour une valeur de 20000f ,un kilo de café pour une valeur de 7000f,05 kg de sucre en poudre pour une valeur de 3000f.

Son objectif est d'augmenter son épargne et assurer les frais de scolarité de ses 02 enfants qui étudient encore.
texts.en:
This group was created in 2011. It is made up of members who live in the same village, their principal activity is small businesses and farming.

The member who is on the far right in the photo with her arm raised is the leader of the group. She is aged 41, and married with six children.

Her main business is catering. She has a little restaurant where she serves breakfast. She has been in this business for 10 years, which means that she has many faithful customers.

With the loan, she plans to buy 10 crates of eggs worth 20000f, a kilo of coffee for 7000f, and half a kilo of caster sugar worth 3000f.

Her aim is to increase her savings and pay the school fees for her two children who are still studying.

loans.use: to buy eggs, sugar, milk and coffee.

loans.name: Diana

texts.en: Due to difficult circumstances, Diana did not have access to any form of formal education, yet this has not stopped her from achieving her dream of becoming an entrepreneur. Currently, Diana sells fish in Funko (near Cape Coast). She has been doing so for about six years. She is married to a fisherman, and together they have three children. Diana uses all her income to feed and provide for her family. Diana will use the loan to purchase an increased amount of fish, which will aid her in improving her overall sales. Diana wants to use the future profits from her expanded business to ensure that all her children are able to receive an education.

loans.use: to purchase more fish to sell

loans.name: Abdallha

texts.en: Abdullah is a sixty year old married man living in Masindi, Uganda. He sells packed water and with the proceeds he has been able to buy land and pay school fees for his children. High costs of operation and inadequate capital hinder his business profits. His dream is to own a big water factory. Abdullah intends to use the loan to buy water packaging materials to use.

loans.use: to buy water packaging materials to use.

loans.name: Reyna Inés

texts.es: La cliente es de la ciudad de Libertad.  Empezó con la confección de muñecas de trapo años atrás y le ha resultado una actividad muy productiva hasta ahora.  Además se dedica a la venta de muebles y repisas.  Trabaja sola, todos los días realizando sus manualidades.  No es casada pero tiene hijos, quienes ya son todos adultos.  Ahora necesita el crédito para la compra de muebles e insumos necesarios para la manufactura de sus productos.
texts.en:
This borrower is from the city of Libertad.  She started making rag dolls years ago and it has resulted in a very productive business that she manages to this day.  In addition, she sells furniture and shelving.  The borrower works alone every day, engaging in her handicrafts.  She is not married, but she has children who are all adults.  

For now, the borrower needs this loan so that she can buy furniture to sell and necessary supplies for making her products.

loans.use: to buy supplies for making rag dolls and furniture to sell.

loans.name: Silverio Feliciano

texts.es: El cliente reside en la ciudad de Libertad.  Tiene mucho tiempo trabajando en la actividad de la pesca y hasta ahora le ha resultado muy productiva.  Trabaja solo, todo el día, todos los días.  Es casado y su esposa trabaja como modista.  Tiene 2 hijos que estudian en la escuela fiscal de su sector.  A futuro espera que su negocio se mantenga y crezca, dado que es el sustento de su familia.  Ahora necesita el dinero del crédito para la compra de pescado para su comercialización.
texts.en:
This borrower resides in the city of Libertad.  He has been working a long time in the business of selling fish and now he has achieved very productive results.  The borrower works alone all day, every day.  He is married and his wife is a seamstress.  They have two children who attend a state school in the area.  In the future, he hopes to maintain and grow his business so that he can support his family.

For now, the borrower needs the money from this loan so that he can buy fish to sell.

loans.use: to buy fish to sell.

loans.name: Magaly

texts.es: La cliente es de la ciudad de Libertad.  Empezó siendo comerciante de ropa y de productos de belleza tiempo atrás, y hasta la fecha, se ha mantenido con esta activdad que le ha resultado muy buena.  Trabaja sola todo el día, cuando realiza sus recorridos.  Es casada y su esposo es chef.  Tiene hijos y estudian en la escuela fiscal.  Desea que su negocio se incremente mucho más a futuro para seguir creciendo económicamente.  Ahora necesita el crédito para la compra de ropa, cremas y perfumes para su venta.
texts.en:
The client is from the city of Libertad.  She started selling clothes and beauty products some time ago.  She has maintained this business activity to date, and it has turned out very well for her.  

She works alone all day, which is when she makes her sales related travels.  She is married, and her husband is a chef.  She has children, and they go to the public school.

She wishes for her business to increase a lot more in the future in order to continue growing financially.  She now needs the loan to buy clothes, creams, and perfumes to sell.

loans.use: to buy merchandise.

loans.name: Mwanasidi

texts.en:
Mwanasidi is widowed and has seven children. She lives at a rental house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

She has operated a food selling business, making dumplings, flat bread for sale. She sells from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. 

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, cooking fat and sugar. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour, cooking fat and sugar.

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en:
Patrick lives in the Litein area of Kenya. He has no children and has been doing this work for 2 years. His primary income sources are milk, crops.

He stated what is most enjoyable about farming: 'keeping dairy cows.' His biggest challenge is 'animal diseases.' Animals on the farm have been given the names of 'cheseger.'

Patrick was asked why he chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which he replied: 'because they give grace period.' This client was also asked what was learned during Juhudi's required micro-finance training session: 'that they encourage group guarantee- mechanism.'

His highest monthly expense is farming costs. When asked 'How will this loan benefit his family', Patrick replied 'in improving their livelihood.'

As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Patrick owns the following: 'cow, pig' but does not own 'poultry, pump, bicycle, motorcycle, automobile'. Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household 'mosquito net' but does not have 'electricity, solar power, running water, sewing machine, TV, DVD'.

loans.use: To purchase poultry.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes sells cereals in Makueni town. These include maize and beans. She has been in this business for 9 years and she makes a monthly income of Kshs. 9,000. She is 34 years old and married to Gideon with whom they have 2 children. 

This being her first loan term she plans to use the loan amount to buy more stock of maize and beans  for selling. She plans to use the anticipated income to pay school fees for her children. 

In future, Agnes hopes and dreams of having a stable business, make more income and be able to provide for the needs of her family.

loans.use: To buy more stock of cereals for selling.

loans.name: Saru

texts.en:
Saru is 34 years-old .  She is Married and has 2 children aged 17 and 4.  Many years ago, she established  her statues making business.  Working 7 days a week and 7 hours a day, she supoorts her family.  She has already received and successfully repaid 2 loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent to buys raw material for her business.  In the future, Saru plans to uplift the economic conditon of her family.  She thanks you for your support. 
  Nepal has a long and rich history of traditional handicrafts.  Throughout the Kathmandu Valley, skilled artisans produce unique pieces of art that reflect Nepal's cultural diversity.  Terra cotta pottery comes from the red clay of the surrounding Himalayan foothills.  Bronze and silver statuettes are formed using wax molds and intricate hand tool finishing.  In Patan, Newari culture and traditions are reflected in the images and symbols etched into metal or formed in stone.  With the help of a Kiva loan, Nepal's artisans are able to purchase raw materials in greater volume.  This increase in volume allows a single artisan to work on several pieces at the same time while increasing her profit margin.

loans.use: to buys raw material for her business

loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
Edna is a single lady aged 24 and her child is 7 years old.  She sells second hand clothings in Kabarnet Location and has been in operation for a period of 3 years earning an income of kes 8,000 monthly.

She is now servicing her first loan of kes 30,000 from KADET LTD and wishes to use this amounts to purchase bales of second hand clothes for resale.  The profits she earns will be used as savings for future investments and developments.

Her dream is live a better life.

loans.use: To purchase bales of second hand clothings

loans.name: Josefa Ferreira

texts.en:
Josefa Ferreira, 47, is married, has 4 children and 1 grandson who she raises. Since small she interested to learn sew, her mother encouraged a lot, she become dressmaker buying magazines and looking patterns.
Josefa, was born in north Brazil, cames too early to state of São Paulo for improve their life.
She got to buy her first sewing machine after much struggle and with her own job.
That time she had supports family alone, due to divorce of first marriage.
Today she makes doll clothes for a company, she needs to buy a machine embroidery, thread and cloth for complement her clothing business and sell for other people and companies, she intends with the loan to double her production and hire an employee.
She teaches her  daughters who are 12 and 14 years to stir in the sewing machine for in the future they may work in family.

loans.use: To buy a machine embroidery, thread and cloth

loans.name: Alex Sandro

texts.en:
Alex Sandro de Lima Menezes, 34, he was born in north Brazil, came to São Paulo seeking better opportunities. 
He´s married, has 3 children, he wants to give a best life and boost  his income generation.
Recently started working with a small garage machine, going to the clients by door to door. He learned this profession with his father.
Alex is keen to purchase a new machine and tools to attend his clients.

loans.use: To buy tools (trunk key) and batteries car

loans.name: Andressa

texts.en: In the wear 2010 Andressa, 18 years old, came, with your family, from “Miracatu”, small town, to Sorocaba São Paulo looking for better opportunities in your life and work conditions. In 2013 she married and was living in a little rented house with your mother-in-law. Nowadays, she’s study, but, she does not have work, is unemployed. For this reason she decided to create your business for help from your family and your dreams. She has one important dream: through the business buy the family home. Andressa need a loan of R$ 500,00 for acquire raw for make chocolate sweet-stuff and candies for sell to neighbors, family and friends. She appreciates the help of all.

loans.use: To buy pans, chocolate, wrapping filling for the bonbon

loans.name: Flora

texts.es:
Flora  se dedica a la producción de quesos, su esposo trabaja como maestro albañil en la ciudad de la Paz, vive con uno solo de sus hijos puesto que los demás ya conformaron su familia propia, los quesos que Ella elabora los vende directamente el publico en días de feria de  de Viacha, considerada ya una ciudad intermedia.
Actualmente vive en su casa propia ubicada en la comunidad de Achica Baja del municipio de Viacha a dos   horas de viaje de la ciudad de La Paz, cuenta con  algunas cabezas de ganado  las cuales le proporcionan leche, con la que elabora su producción de queso en condiciones sumamente higiénicas de tal manera que sus quesos son muy limpios y de mejor calidad.
El crédito  requiere para comprar una vaca lechera y así incrementar su producción de queso

El sueño de Flora es incrementar sus cabezas de ganado.
Es la tercera  vez que solicita crédito junto a IMPRO y la segunda vez con KIVA.
texts.en:
Flora works producing cheese and her husband’s a master builder in the city of La Paz.  She lives just with one of her children for the rest have already formed their own families.  She sells the cheese she make directly to the public on market days in Viacha which is now considered to be a medium-size city.

She currently lives in her own house located in the community of Achica Baja in Viacha municipality, a two-hour trip from the city of La Paz.  She owns a few head of cattle that produce the milk she uses to make the cheese in highly hygienic conditions to guarantee the cleanliness and high quality of the cheese.  

She needs the loan to buy a dairy cow to increase cheese production.  Flor’s dream is to buy a dairy cow to increase cheese production.  This is her third IMPRO loan request and second with KIVA.

loans.use: to buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Marcos Antonio

texts.en: Marcos Antonio, 26 years old, is married and is father the two children, one with 8 and other 2 years old. He was born in Recife (Brazil northeast) and looking for better life and work he got to São Paulo (Brazil southeast). Marcos work with night watchman and hawker religious articles and clothes, whiles your wife is housemaid. For the growth the sales, Marcos want to expand your small religious store with the objective of is only work in your business. He request is R$ 3000,00 for buy building construction ( brick, cement, and others).With this loan, Marcos will reform your small religious clothes store. He appreciates the help of all.

loans.use: To buy building construction ( brick, cement, and others) reform your small religious clothes store

loans.name: Sahie Solomon

texts.en: This is 45-year-old Sahie. He is married and has three children who are 24, 9 and 5 years old. He has four additional dependents who live with him for schooling.  In 2010, Sahid established his Drinks (Bar) business. He began his business because he wanted to become self employed. Working 7 days a week and 15 hours a day, he earns about Le 800,000 every month from this business. He would like a loan of Le 5,000,000. Sahid requires a loan in order to buy more drinks of different kinds for resale. In the future, Sahid plans to build a bigger entertainment center and educate his children up to the university level. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more drinks for resale.

loans.name: Maria Jose

texts.en:
Maria Jose, 37, came from northern Brazil to try to and improve her life in the big city. She had the idea to start reselling clothes, and with the profit will buy more merchandise. After a time, she wants to assemble her shop in the garage of her residence.

She lives with her husband and two children. Her mother is also coming from the north to live in the house next door, which will help her to settle in the new city.

The money will be used to buy more merchandise in order to increase sales.

loans.use: to buy more merchandise like slipper, clothes, and toys

loans.name: Martina Emerita

texts.es: La cliente es de la ciudad de Libertad.  Decidió que debía aportar con sus ingresos para ayudar en los gastos del hogar.  Por este motivo emprendió en la venta de ropa entre sus familiares y amigos principalmente.  Trabaja todos los días, tanto en la mañana como en la tarde, de acuerdo a sus pedidos.  Es casada y su esposo trabaja en el Municipio.  Tiene 4 hijos, una estudia en la escuela fiscal y los otros ya son mayores de edad.  Sueña con aumentar sus ingresos y mejorar su negocio.  Ahora, requiere el crédito para la compra de más ropa para su comercialización.

loans.use: Compra de mercadería

loans.name: Jazmina Isabel

texts.es: Jazmina habita en Managua, es una señora muy trabajadora, la cual tiene muchos años en su negocio, ella provee a los habitantes de su barrio de tres alimentos básicos ya procesados, a pesar que su esposo trabaja como guarda de seguridad, este ingreso no cubre todas las necesidades de su casa, el gran apoyo que ella ha brindado  ha permitido que sus dos hijos sean mayores y trabajen. Jazmina solicita el crédito para comprar la materia prima maíz para la elaboración de sus tortillas, comprar queso fresco y frijoles que lo comercializa cosido a su fiel clientela en el barrio.
texts.en: Jazmina habita en Managua, es una señora muy trabajadora, la cual tiene muchos años en su negocio, ella provee a los habitantes de su barrio de tres alimentos básicos ya procesados, a pesar que su esposo trabaja como guarda de seguridad, este ingreso no cubre todas las necesidades de su casa, el gran apoyo que ella ha brindado  ha permitido que sus dos hijos sean mayores y trabajen. Jazmina solicita el crédito para comprar la materia prima maíz para la elaboración de sus tortillas, comprar queso fresco y frijoles que lo comercializa cosido a su fiel clientela en el barrio.

loans.use: comprar la materia prima maíz, queso fresco y frijoles.

loans.name: Violeta

texts.en:
Violeta is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a vegetable selling business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing 27,000 PHP through NWTF to buy vegetables to sell for her business.

Violeta has been in this business for 10 years. Violeta earns more income from raising pigs and farming vegetables.

Violeta has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving enough money so she could afford to send her children to college in the future.

loans.use: to buy vegetables to sell

loans.name: Sylvester

texts.en:
Sylvester is a 39-year-old married man. He has six children. He describes himself as innovative. 

He operates a business where he makes jikos (cook stoves) for sale. He has been involved in this business for three years. His business is located in a competitive area and his primary customers are of all types. He describes his biggest business challenge as lack of capital. 

He will use the KES 60,000 loan to buy metal sheets, nails and other items to make more jikos for sale. His business goal is to have a big shop within five years. This is his second loan with SMEP DTM. He will use the anticipated profits to add more stock of jikos.

loans.use: to buy metal sheets, nails and other items

loans.name: Marlyn

texts.en:
Marlyn works hard to support her family. Marlyn is married and has a tailoring business in the Philippines. Marlyn has been in this business for two years now.

Marlyn requested a PHP 7,000 loan through NWTF to buy more materials like cloth, zippers, tape measure, etc.

In the future, Marlyn would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy more materials like cloth, zippers, tape measure, etc

loans.name: Oliver

texts.en: Oliver is a new client of UGAFODE Microfinance – Ishaka branch and she has six children aged 30, 28, 25, 21, 17 and 14 with the last four of the six in school. She is a farmer who devotes twelve hours per day to the farming business. She works six days each week and when she is off the farm, she attends to her bar which is her other source of income. She started farming in 1999 and has not turned back since then for it has been her major source of income to sustain her family and she has high hopes that she will be financially stable if the loan is given since it will give her profits in the long run. Her clients are cattle traders in the area and she hopes to use the money to buy more cattle which she intends to fatten and sell at a profit. Her challenge is lack of capital but she believes that if she is given the loan and stays the shrewd farmer she has always been, she will succeed in life.

loans.use: To buy cattle

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
Emily is 31 years old and lives in P-Makiangayon, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental, Mindanao: Philippines. In order to help her husband to support their family, she is engaged in a direct-selling business. She sells products like cosmetics, men's and women's clothing, and others. In addition to her direct-selling activities, she operates a sari-sari (convenience) store.

She applied for membership with Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative and became an active member, with good credit standing. Now, she wants to obtain financial assistance in the amount of PHP 15,000. She will use the loan to purchase more goods for her sari-sari store, because what she has been earning is not sufficient for her daily needs. She plans to send her children to college, so that they can help her in the future. She wants them to help her to repair the house and to live comfortably with her family.

loans.use: to buy additional goods for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Salma

texts.en:
With 16 years experience in the field of sewing and tailoring, Salma understands the sector, her clients and the concept of supply and demand very well. She also knows that sometimes it is best to change a business and its profile to respond to the costumers' needs and run a profitable small enterprise based on the new directions.

Salma started as a woman's dressmaker in 1997, but since 2010 she is a partner and tailor in a men's suits workshop - a much more profitable and demanded service providing business. The small enterprise is a shared family business and fits perfectly with the demand for having quality traditional suits for men. The imported men clothes do not suit the local market needs neither in design nor in functionality and cultural acceptance.

The demand for Salma's products is high and Salma would like to increase the productivity of the workshop and expand its capacity. An important item for the expansion is a specific equipment, a machine that works well with the thick, quality suit fabrics. 
With the potential for growing her business, Salma qualifies to participate in the WLIFT program and is taking a loan from Relief International Microfinance Iraq in the amount of 14,000 USD for the expansion of the tailoring workshop and the purchase of equipment for the enlarged business.    

Salma is enthusiastic about learning more about how to improve her business managerial skills. With a highly positive attitude she is an ambitious and hard working tailor, at the same time she is also a wife and a mother of 3 children. At the age of 40 she is already a role model to many other Iraqi women in her area, having earned much respect for both the quality of her work and her dedication to the business.

Based on the political and social challenges of lending in Iraq, personally identifiable information about this borrower has been altered for their protection. RI-Iraq appreciates Kiva lenders' consideration of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Iraqi borrowers.

loans.use: to expand the tailoring workshop and the purchase equipment for the enlarged business.

loans.name: Hadjah

texts.en: Hadjah is a single mother of two children; one of her children goes to school. She doesn’t take care of additional family members. She has a business of selling green bananas and has been in this business for seven years. She has applied for a loan of 300,000 Ugandan shillings from MCDT-SACCO to buy more bunches of green bananas. She works from home seven days out of every week and sells to all categories of people on retail. She doesn’t have any other income-generating activity. Her major business challenges include seasonality and defaulting. She is aspiring to go to the villages of Masaka for green bananas and also to educate her children up to university level. She resides in the family house and the family has access to electricity but not to piped water. Her monthly expenses includes school fees and paying for electricity bills.

loans.use: to buy more bunches of green bananas.

loans.name: Gbenondou-Pahou 2 Group

texts.fr: Le groupement GBENONDOU-PAHOU 2 est composé de trente un personnes qui habitent le même quartier. C'est la première fois que ce groupe, sollicite l'aide financier de ALIDé afin d’élever le niveau de leur Le activité. La représentante du groupe, nommée Ayabavi Séverine Olivia est celle qui a la main levée sur la photo. Ayabavi Séverine Olivia est âgée de 44 ans et est mariée à un certain Florent. Le couple a trois enfants, tous scolarisés et à leur charge. Ayabavi Séverine Olivia vit avec son mari et ses enfants. Les diverses charges de la maison sont assurées par le couple. Pour y parvenir, Ayabavi Séverine Olivia vend des vêtements et des tissus depuis sept ans de façon ambulante. Ayabavi Séverine Olivia s’approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle et pour accroître son chiffre d’affaires et son revenu, Ayabavi Séverine Olivia  sollicite ensemble avec les autres membres du groupe GBENONDOU-PAHOU 2 un premier crédit.
texts.en:
The Gbenondou-Pahou 2 group has 31 members who all live in the same district. This is the first time that the group requests financial support from ALIDé, in order to increase the levels of their business. The group's representative, Ayabavi Séverine Olivia, is the one with her hand raised in the picture.

Ayabavi Séverine Olivia is 44 years old and married to Florent. The couple have 3 dependent children who all attend school. Ayabavi Séverine Olivia lives with her husband and children. The couple both take care of the various household expenses. In order to be able to do this, Ayabavi Séverine Olivia has been selling clothing and fabrics on the street for 7 years. Ayabavi Séverine Olivia gets her supplies at a market in Benin. In order to be able to satisfy her customers and increase her turnover, Ayabavi Séverine Olivia is requesting a first loan, together with the other member of the Gbenondou-Pahou 2 group.

loans.use: to buy clothing and fabrics.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice lives in the Kisii area of Kenya, which is scarce of available land.  She has 4 children and has been doing farming for 12 years. Her primary income source is milk.

Alice stated that what is most enjoyable about farming is 'milking her dairy cows.'   Her biggest challenge is 'weeding her crops.'   Animals on the farm have been given the names of 'Nyamotika.'

Alice was asked why she chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which she replied: 'Better services.'  This client was also asked what was learned during Juhudi's required micro-finance training session and answered:  'Low interest  rate.'

Alice's highest monthly expense is school fees. When asked 'How will this loan benefit the family?'  Alice replied 'Improve the living standards.'  

Alice owns the following: 'cow' but does not own 'pig, poultry, pump, bicycle, motorcycle, automobile'.   Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household 'mosquito net' but does not have 'electricity, solar power, running water, sewing machine, TV, DVD'.

loans.use: buy a water tank

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Meet 39-year-old Mary Wanjiku from Muranga. Like many residents of Muranga who farm and export coffee, Mary has been doing this work for three years. She owns a pump and mosquito net, but does not own any cows, pigs, poultry, bicycles, motorcycles, or automobiles. Mary has running water, but does not have electricity, solar power, a sewing machine, DVD, or other modern devices.

To make ends meet, she also engages in crop farming, fish farming and personal business. Mary says that even though initial farming preparations are challenging, harvesting gives her great joy. Having said that, she also explained that her highest monthly expense goes to farming costs. She is therefore applying for this loan so that she can get funding to expand her fish farming project as it will boost her income and improve her livelihood. 

Mary was asked why she chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which she replied it was because unlike other MFI's, Juhudi gives agricultural loans. When asked about her key learnings from Juhudi's microfinance training sessions, she said she learned about how to develop a culture of saving.

loans.use: To do fish farming.

loans.name: Avec-Mali

texts.en:
AVEC-Mali is a women’s association based in Mopti, Mali with 74 members. The association engages in a variety of activities, such as selling clean cookstoves, teaching women to read and write and educating women about family planning.  

In July, nine women from the association starting selling solar lamps (seven of them are featured in the photo).  As of the end of September they sold 1,200 lamps and they have ambitious plans to grow the sales. 

Korotoumou (fourth from the left) is one of nine members of AVEC-Mali who sell solar lamps. She is 47 years old and has six children. In addition to her work with the women’s association, Korotoumou is the matron at a health center in Mopti, and she sells grains.  In July, she started selling solar lamps to fisherman, students and farmers, who are reliant on kerosene and flashlights for light.  With a solar lamp, her customers can save money.  Kerosene and mobile phone charging currently cost about $110 per year; whereas, a solar lamp costs $25 and has a lifetime of about five years.  These solar lamps provide 8 hours of light and can charge a mobile phone.

On top of being less expensive, solar lamps are more durable and reliable and keep people from stealing mobile phones. “With a solar lamp, you don’t have to go to a mobile phone charging station and give your phone to someone who may steal your phone or use the call credit you have on your phone,” says Korotoumou.

Selling solar lamps provides income for the women and for the association. The women earn $2 for every lamp they sell and the association earns $3.  The money the association earns is invested in a warehouse to store solar lamp inventory and motorcycles to distribute the products.

The solar saleswomen are well organized – each responsible for her own sales territory. They educate their communities about the benefits of solar lights and generate lamp sales through group meetings and demonstrations at night.

Since customers cannot afford to pay for the lamps up front, the women need working capital. A Kiva loan will allow the solar saleswomen to obtain solar lamp inventory from NOTS Lampe Solaire on credit.  When they receive payment from their customers they will re-pay the Kiva loan.

loans.use: to buy solar lamps that they will sell in their communities

loans.name: Gombre Group

texts.fr:
Mr SAYOUBA représente le groupe  GOMBRE. Il est célibataire sans enfant.
Mr est tailleur depuis 04ans. Il s’approvisionne au marché de son secteur en ville. Ses clients sont les amis et voisins.
Mr veut s’acheter 01 rouleau de popeline, 01paquet de fermeture et 01boite de boutons confondus.
Il épargne ses bénéfices. Mr ambitionne agrandir son d’activité et aider ses parents dans les charges  familiales.
texts.en: Sayouba represents the Gombre group. He is unmarried and has no children. He has been a tailor for 4 years. Sayouba stocks up at the market in his town. His customers are friends and neighbors. He wants to purchase 1 roll of poplin, 1 package of closures, and 1 box of assorted buttons, and plans to save his profits. Sayouba's goal is to expand his business and to help his parents with the family expenses.

loans.use: to purchase 1 roll of poplin, 1 package of closures, and 1 box of assorted buttons

loans.name: Jessica Carolina

texts.es: La cliente es de la ciudad de Libertad.  Empezó con su negocio de venta de comidas cuando se dio cuenta que en el sitio de trabajo de su cónyuge, laboran varias personas que no van desayunando de su casa por cuestión de tiempo.  Trabaja diariamente, prepara los desayunos y los reparte muy temprano en la mañana.  Es casada y su esposo se dedica a la venta de marquetas de hielo.  Tiene 3 hijos y estudian en la escuela fiscal que está cerca de su casa, la cual es fiscal.  Desea que en un futuro, su clientela se incremente mucho más, para poder mejorar sus ingresos.  Ahora requiere el crédito para la compra de abarrotes y ollas para la preparación de los alimentos que vende.

loans.use: Compra de abarrotes y utensilios

loans.name: Nelson

texts.en:
Meet Nelson who lives in Kisii. This is a very fertile area where bananas and sugarcane do very well. He is married and has 6 children. Farming has been part of his life for close to 40 years. Nelson has the following: cows, poultry, mosquito net, solar power, running water, sewing machine, TV, and DVD,' but does not have pigs, pump, bicycle, motorcycle, automobile, or electricity.

His primary income sources are milk, eggs, tea, and crops. He says that marketing his farm output poses a major challenge to him, while selling the milk produced poses greater joy. Some farmers usually name their animals and Nelson is one of them, and has given his cow the name of 'Nyansanoko'.

When asked how Juhudi Kilimo has benefited him, he said that it helped him expand his dairy farm by giving him a loan to purchase a dairy cow. This client was also asked what was learned during Juhudi's required micro-finance training session: 'How to develop a saving culture.'

His highest monthly expenses are farming costs. When asked how will this loan benefit his family, Nelson replied: 'it will provide for their basic needs through the increased income'.

loans.use: to purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Alex

texts.en: Alex is a young resident of the Kawangware slum. He does not have any parents and has spent much of his childhood days in welfare organisations for street youth.  He was previously involved in crime, had repeated periods of unemployment and had taken odd jobs on the street for extremely low wages.  He describes himself as ambitious and determined.  He now sells eco-friendly products such as solar lamps and fuel-efficient cookstoves in slums around Nairobi.  He will use the loan to buy more stock to sell so that he can earn a decent wage and help his community.

loans.use: To purchase stock to sell

loans.name: Maravilla Group

texts.es: Rosa, quien aparece sentada en la fotografía junto a una niña, pertenece al Banco Comunal Maravilla, de Cañete VIII Región de Chile. En este Banco el principal rubro es el comercio, tales como venta de flores, comida rápida, venta de joyas y ropa. Rosa vende ropa hace 16 años, ella comenzó de ayudante vendiendo puerta a puerta hasta que decidió independizarse. Problemas ha tenido dos muy importantes respecto a su negocio, el primero es que debió cerrar su negocio por problemas personales y el segundo fue que también debió cerrar su negocio por no pago de clientas a las cuales les dio crédito. Esto le ayudo a tener más precaución para su futuro. El dinero que solicita lo ocupará para  comprar ropa y arrendar un nuevo local. Piensa que será un buen tiempo para la venta de ropa, y lo que más le ha gustado de trabajar junto a Fondo Esperanza es el hecho de poder encontrar  coordinación, ayuda y comunicación.
texts.en:
Rosa, who is sitting with a girl in the picture, is a member of Communal Bank “Maravilla,” in the Cañete VIII region, Chile. The group’s members work all with commercial activities, such as selling flowers, fast food, jewelry and clothes. Rosa has been selling clothes for sixteen years. She started as an assistant, selling clothes door-to-door until she decided to become an independent saleswoman.

She has had two big problems with her business. The first one was when she had to close her business due to private issues and the second one was when she had to close it because her customers were not paying on time. These experiences helped her to be more cautious in the future. She is requesting a loan to buy clothes and rent a new establishment. She believes this is a good season to sell clothes. What she likes the most about working with Fondo Esperanza is that she finds coordinated activities, support and communication.

loans.use: to buy clothes to sell.
